text: 10. My findings on the above Points are: Point No.1: In the Affirmative.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Point No.2: In the Negative.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Point No.3: As per final order for following REASONS 11.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Point No.1:
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Learned Counsel appearing for the appellant vehemently canvassed that the plaintiff who is a Lingayath is married to Annapurna and has got two children in the said wed lock.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Family Court while disposing of the C.Mis. filed by the defendants' mother held that the she is not the legally wedded wife of the plaintiff.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Trail Court erred in not properly appreciating Ex.P3 sworn to by DW1 and produced before the school authorities seeking change of the defendants' father's name as `Yusuf' in the place of Suresh.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: DNA test was not done to confirm the paternity.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 12. Per contra, the Learned Counsel for the respondents supported the judgment and decree of the Trial Court.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: It was contended by him that since the plaintiff has not chosen to assail the judgment in RPFC 8/2004, the finding that the defendants are the children of the plaintiff has become final.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: In Ex.P3, a printed Form there is a huge blank space between the typed matter and DW1's signature, which is not even identified by anybody.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Merely because the signature is affixed in English it cannot be presumed that DW1 is a literate.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Ex.P3 is a concocted document.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 13. In the light of the above rival contentions, if the evidence on record is carefully examined, it is seen that, the question whether PW1 is married to Annapurna and has children through her is irrelevant for the purpose of this case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The trial court thus has rightly held that the Ex.P7 to Ex.P13 are not material to the matter in issue.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14. Further, the findings of the Family Court in C.Mis.135/00 that the mother of the defendants is not the legally wedded wife of the plaintiff has reached finality, as the said order is confirmed by the Hon'ble High Court of Karnataka, in RPFC No.8/2004.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further no relief is claimed against her in the suit filed by the plaintiff.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 15. The only issue that requires to be considered is whether the defendants are the children of the plaintiff or not?
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff to discharge the burden cast upon him, relies mainly on Ex.P3 which is an affidavit sworn to by Sabeena Parveen for change of her husband's name in the school records Yousuf on the ground that it is wrongly entered as Suresh in respect of her daughter Fathimmunnisa.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 16. On perusal of Ex.P3 it is seen that there is a huge gap between the typed portion and DW1's signature which is not even identified by any Advocate.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex.P3 is said to have been sworn to before certain S.Sundararaja Iyengar, a Notary on 24.7.1997.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
DW1 categorically states that the plaintiff admitted Fathimunnisa to C.K.C.Convent and that she has not appeared before any Notary on 24.07.1997.
 17.
label: ANALYSIS

text: No doubt Ex.P6, report of the expert commissioner is to the effect that the signature of DW1 on Ex.P3 is the same as the one found on the vakalathnama and the written statement filed by DW1 on behalf of minor defendants in this case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 specifically states that the name of the first defendant's father as seen in the birth certificate Ex.P5 was entered as instructed by the plaintiff.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 18. Ex.D1 is the Certificate issued by Christ Convent, 30.1.2003 to the effect that the 1st defendant is the daughter of G.Suresh i.e., the plaintiff and that she is a student of their Institution; her date of birth is 15.9.1990 as per the school records.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex.D9 is the Antenatal Card issued by the Dr.B.Nirmala, a Consultant Gynecologist wherein DW1's husband's name is shown as Suresh.
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 has stated that this document pertains to the 1st defendant.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19. Ex
label: ANALYSIS

text: .D10 is the birth certificate in respect of the 1st defendant wherein the name of her parents is shown as Suresh and Sabeena.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex.D11 is the voters list extract obtained on 3.3.94 wherein the plaintiff and DW1 are shown as husband and wife.
label: ANALYSIS

text: DW1 claims that the plaintiff at the relevant point of time furnished these particulars.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 20. PW1 pleads ignorance to the suggestion that the 2nd defendant Hazira was born while he was living with DW1 in Vivekanandanagara.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also claims to be not knowing the contents of Ex.P3 and if the signature thereon is not made by DW1.
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW1 says that he does not know who handed over Ex.P3 to School authorities.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21. PW2, H.M. of C K C Convent unequivocally admits that in Ex.P2, the 1st defendant's father's name is entered as G.Suresh and even in the application submitted at the time of her admission it was mentioned so.
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to PW2 only during 2004, on the basis of Ex.P3 she has struck off `Suresh' in Ex.P5 and changed it as `Yusuf' that after the plaintiff brought filing of such affidavit to her knowledge.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
The relevant portion of PW2's evidence reads as under: "zj Cqm 2004 g  UP    zU Agvz. .B13.1.2005 gAz Ai zj Ai  UP vAgvg. -3 C U Aiig vAz Pngvg JAz U Uw. zj wzr iq Aiz  zj  wzr Ai 1 wUU Cx          Cg  vAi UPU  vg. .3 C x jU  PzU rz."
 22.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Further PW2 states that she does not know who effected corrections in Ex.P6, which was admittedly, issued on 10.4.2000 much prior to PW2 noticing Ex.P3.
label: ANALYSIS

text: How the plaintiff came to know about existence of Ex.P3? remains unanswered.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 23. Ex.D5 is NCR issued by the SHO of Ashokapuram Police Station, Mysore to DW1 in respect of a complaint against her husband Suresha.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex.D8 is the endorsement issued on 1.7.2000, with respect to this complaint.
label: ANALYSIS

text: If at all the plaintiff was not at all known to DW1 as claimed, how DW1 could give his name as her husband's name or lodge a complaint against him as early as in 1990 and year 2000
label: ANALYSIS

text: has also remained unanswered.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 24. On perusal Ex.P14, it is seen that the Family Court had held that the plaintiff herein and DW1 though were residing together as husband and wife, yet DW1 could not be his legally wedded wife on account of the fact that she had remained a Muslim.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This finding has not bee set aside, varied or modified by the Hon'ble High Court of Karnataka in RPFC. No.8/2004.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the same has reached finality.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 25. The evidence on record indicates that PW2 on being prompted by the plaintiff has struck off the plaintiff's name appearing in the 1st defendant's school records without intimating the defendants or their mother.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex.P3 is dated 24.7.1997, but PW2 has acted upon the same somewhere during the year 2005.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore it appears that on account of his strained relationship with DW1 the plaintiff has engineered changes in the entries made in the school records.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 26. Ex.P15, 17 and 18 are issued by the statutory authorities such as Election Commission, City Corporation, Mysore and these documents speak to the effect that the plaintiff and DW1 were residing together as husband and wife; and the 1st defendant was born to them.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff is bound by his documents and cannot retract from its contents.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 27. Ex.D1, Certificate dated 30.1.2003 issued by the H.M. of C.K.C. Higher Primary School, Mysore, in respect of 2nd defendant and Ex.D4 issued by the Dy.Director of Public Instructions
label: ANALYSIS

text:
clearly establish that the plaintiff is the father of the defendants.
 28.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Paternity is a question of fact.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff is just hanging on to Ex.P3 to prove his case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Having disputed his relationship with the defendants, the plaintiff till date has not come forward to undergo DNA test.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
Further the circumstances, under which Ex.P3 has come into existence being doubtful, I am of the considered view that no relationship can be placed upon Ex.P3.
 29.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Trial court by considering all the probabilities and after careful evaluation of the evidence on record has come to the right, just and proper conclusion that the plaintiff is the father of the defendants.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore the point for consideration is answered in the affirmative.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 30. Point No.2:
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: The Learned Counsel for the appellant relies upon the decision in Madhusudan Das Vs Narayani Bai & Ors. reported in AIR 1983 SC 114 wherein it is held that: "In an appeal against a Trial Court decree, when the appellate court considers an issue turning on oral evidence it must bear in mind that it does not enjoy the advantage which the trial court had in having the witnesses before it and of observing the manner in which they gave their testimony.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: When there is a conflict of oral evidence on any matter in issue and its resolution turns upon the credibility of the witnesses, the general rule is that the appellate court should permit the findings of fact rendered by the trial court to prevail unless it clearly appears that some special feature about the evidence of a particular witness has escaped the notice of the trial court or there is a sufficient balance of improbability to displace its opinion as to where the credibility lies."
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: This decision in my view is more helpful to the respondent rather than the appellant and therefore it is not applicable to the appellant's case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 31. The decision in Bishwanath Rai Vs Sachhidanand Singh reported in AIR 1971 SC 1949 and Murarilal Vs State of M.P. reported in AIR 1980 SC 531 are in respect of section 101 and 45, 46, 373, 114 of the Evidence Act.
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: These decisions are also not of any help to the appellant as this court is not after proof of authorship of Ex.P3, but only the circumstances under which it has come to existence and its genuineness.
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: Similarly the decision in Mobarik Ali Ahmed Vs The state of Bombay reported in AIR 1957 SC 857 is also not applicable to the facts of this case.
label: PRE_NOT_RELIED

text: 32. For the fore going reasons I am of the considered view that the findings given by the Trial Court in the impugned judgment and decree is well founded and the same does not call for any interference.
label: RATIO

text: Accordingly point for consideration is answered in the negative.
label: RATIO

text: 33. Point No.3: In the result, I pass the following: ORDER
label: RPC

text: The Regular appeal filed under order 41 rule 1 of CPC is hereby rejected with cost of Rs.1000/-.

text:
The plaintiff has filed this suit against the defendants for the relief of ejectment directing the defendants to hand over vacant possession of the suit schedule property, recovery of arrears of rent of Rs.4,29,900/- and damages for illegal occupation.
 2.
label: FAC

text: The case of the plaintiff in brief are as follows:-
label: FAC

text: The plaintiff has contended that the defendant is the tenant of the suit schedule property under late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan s/o late Dr. Ahamed Hussain Khan, who had given GPA to his brother Mohammed Jamal Khan to look after the schedule premises.
label: FAC

text: On 1-8-1995, the defendant agreed to pay rent at Rs.2282/- with increase of rent at 15% once in three years and paying rents to the GPA holder Mohammed Jamal Khan, as and when becomes due, the same has been made in writing on 1-9- 1996.
label: FAC

text: After death of Jamal Khan on 8th December 1996, rent was being paid to his son-in-law Dr. Syed Zakiuddin Ali from January 1997 to May 2000 by the defendant and receipts were issued.
label: FAC

text:
Thereafter, defendant has stopped paying rents to Dr.
Ahmedulla Khan or Dr. Syed Zakiuddin Ali.
label: FAC

text: Defendant has been informed about the death of Dr. Ahmedulla Khan, who died in May 2005.
label: FAC

text: Legal representatives of said late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan have divided the properties through registered partition deed dt.5-4-2006 and the schedule property has fallen to the share of the plaintiffs.
label: FAC

text: This fact is also made known to thed,, by providing khata of the property in their name in September 2008 and plaintiffs have demanded rents due from the defendant, but the defendant has not chosen to pay the arrears of rent to the plaintiffs.
label: FAC

text: Plaintiffs issued legal notice to the defendant stating that the schedule premises is required for the use of the plaintiffs reasonably and they have terminated the tenancy of the defendant ending on 31st October 2009 and requested the defendant to vacate and hand over the schedule premises and also demanded the arrears of rent.
label: FAC

text: The defendant sent an untenable reply but admitted that he is due rent from June 2000 to the owner of the schedule property, further contended that late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan had no issues.
label: FAC

text: Hence, this suit.
label: FAC

text: 3. After registration of the suit, summons was issued to the defendant.
label: FAC

text: The defendant appeared through his counsel and filed written statement contending that the suit is not maintainable either in law or on facts.
label: FAC

text: He admitted that he is tenant under late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan.
label: FAC

text: He contended that plaintiffs have no right to claim any arrears of rent as they are strangers to the property in question.
label: FAC

text: He admitted that he is tenant under late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan under the registered Lease deed dt.27-9- 1984 and lease period was for 58 months from 1st October 1984 and initially rate of rent is Rs.1,500/- p.m.
label: FAC

text: He admitted that GPA holder of late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan Mohammed Jamal Khan used to collect the rent and defendant enhanced rent to lRs.3,000/- p.m. which was collected till May 2000.
label: FAC

text: Thereafter, said GPA holder did not turn up though defendant intended to pay rent.
label: FAC

text: Said late Dr. Ahmedulla Khan had no heirs-at-law nor legal representatives to succeed to his estate.
label: FAC

text: Without seeking the relief of declaration of title, considering the prayer of the plaintiffs does not arise.
label: FAC

text: Defendant remitted a sum of Rs.42,262/- towards assessment payable.
label: FAC

text: Plaintiffs have no enforceable rights in relation to the suit schedule property.
label: FAC

text: Defendant has never recognised the plaintiffs as his landlords.
label: FAC

text: Hence, prayed for dismissal of the suit.
label: FAC

text: 4. On the basis of the above pleadings, this court has framed the following:- :: I S S U E S :: 1.
label: ISSUE

text: Whether the plaintiffs prove that they are the absolute owner of the suit schedule?
label: ISSUE

text: 2. Whether the plaintiffs prove that the defendant is a tenant under him ?
label: ISSUE

text: 3. Whether the plaintiffs prove that he has terminated the tenancy by issuing legal notice ?
label: ISSUE

text: 4. Whether the plaintiffs prove that defendant is liable to pay arrears of rent for a sum of Rs.4,29,900/- ?
label: ISSUE

text: 5. Whether the plaintiffs are entitled for the vacant possession of the suit schedule property with damages as prayed in the suit ?
label: ISSUE

text: 6. What Order or Decree?
label: ISSUE

text: Issue No.3: In the affirmative.

text: Issue No.6:  As per the final order for the following: - :: R E A S O N S :: 8. ISSUE NOs.1 & 2:-  Since these Issues are interconnected with each other, they are taken up togethr in order to avoid repetition of discussion.

text: 9. The above pleadings show that there is an assertion from the side of the plaintiffs that the defendant is the tenant under late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan and after his death, his legal representatives have divided the property through registered Partition deed dt.5-4-2006.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This fact was made known to the defendant and the plaintiffs have demanded the rent due to them, but the defendant has not chosen to pay arrears of rent to the plaintiffs.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence, the plaintiffs are constrained to issue legal notice dt.31-10-2009.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case of the defendant is that there is no relationship of landlord and tenant between himself and the plaintiffs.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The original landlord Dr. Ahamedulla Khan died and he had had no Issues.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs are not the legal representatives of late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The very title of the plaintiffs is disputed.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence, the suit for eviction is not maintainable without seeking the relief of declaration.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 10. In this regard, both the parties have let their evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

label: ANALYSIS

text: 11. An attempt was made to elicit something in the cross- examination of Pw-1, but she successfully withstood the test of cross-examination.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though Dw-1 has reiterated the written statement averments in his examination-in-chief, but in the cross-examination, the learned Counsel for the plaintiffs has elicited some important admissions and the same will be discussed at a later point of time.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12. Dw-1 got marked the cheque book as Ex.D-1, 16 rent paid receipts as Ex.D-2 to Ex.D-17, Notice dt.30-11-2004issued by the Mysore City Corporation as Ex.D-18, Tax paid receipt dt.10- 1-2005 as Ex.D-19, Accounts extract of the defendant as Ex.D- 20, Paper publication dt.11-12-2004 in Vijaya Karnataka daily newspaper as Ex.D-21 and Ex.D-21(a).
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13. The learned Counsel for the plaintiffs has argued that, the suit schedule property fallen to the share of the plaintiffs through registered Partition deed dt.5-4-2006.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: After coming to know of this fact also, the defendant did not pay arrears of rent.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: Hence, the tenancy was duly terminated on 31-10-2009.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: 14. Per contra, the learned Counsel for the defendant has filed written arguments admitting the jural relationship between him and late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: He further contended that he demise of late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan during May 2005 was informed to the defendant is disputed and registered partition deed is not a sustainable document.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text:
There was no heirs to Dr.
Ahamedulla Khan.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: The allegation of the plaintiffs that the property came to be recorded in the names of the plaintiffs is also disputed by the defendant.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Plaintiffs have no right to claim any arrears as they are strangers.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: As there is no relationship of landlord and tenant between himself and the plaintiffs, the suit of the plaintiffs is not maintainable.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: Without considering the right of the plaintiffs in the absence of any suit and decree from the competent Court of law, plaintiffs are not entitled to any of the reliefs.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: From these construction of the parties and documents, the fact remains is that whether the tenant can deny title of the landlord.
label: ARG_RESPONDENT

text: 15.  With these contentions taken up by the parties, I have perused the pleadings, evidence and other materials on record.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs have contended that the suit schedule property fallen to their share through registered partition deed dt.5-4-2006.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of the plaintiffs that late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan is the landlord and defendant is the tenant under the plaintiff.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
Dr.
 Ahamedulla Khan had given GPA to his brother Mohammed Jamal Khan in respect of the the suit schedule property and the defendant agreed to pay rent at the rate of Rs.2282/- with an increase of rent at 15% once in three years.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly, defendant was paying rent to the GPA holder Mohammed Jamal Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The claim is not disputed by the defendant.
label: ANALYSIS

text: After the demise of Mohammed Jamal Khan, the rent was being paid to his son-in-law Syed Zakiuddin Ali from January 1997to June 2000 by the defendant and receipts were issued.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter, defendant stopped paying the rent.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Said Dr. Ahamedulla Khan died during May 2005.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The legal representatives of the deceased Dr. Ahmedulla Khan have divided the properties of late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan through registered partition deed dt.5- 4-2006 and the suit schedule property has fallen to the share of the plaintiffs who are the sons and daughters of Mohammed Jamal Khan, who was the brother of late Dr. Ahamedulla Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
In this case, the defendant has not disputed the landlord and tenant relationship between himself and the deceased Dr.
Ahmadulla Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
It is the only defence of the defendant that the plaintiffs are not the legal representatives of the deceased Dr.
Ahmadulla Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The defendant himself in his cross- examination has admitted that the deceased Dr. Ahmadulla Khan has no issue.
label: ANALYSIS

text: At Ex.P-6 which is the registered Partition deed, the defendants and other legal representatives of Dr. Ahmadulla Khan have stated that the wife of the said Dr. Ahmadulla Khan has taken a voluntary divorce long back.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
Further, defendants have produced the genealogical tree which is marked at Ex.P-15 shows that plaintiffs are also legal heirs of the deceased Dr.
Ahmadulla Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
The other legal representatives of Dr.
Ahmadulla Khan have also filed declaration at Ex.P-17 to Ex.P-19 stating that the suit schedule property originally belongs to their brother Dr. Ahmadulla Khan and he died leaving behind him, the defendants and themselves as his legal heirs.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Ex.P-6 which is the registered Partition deed clearly shows that the plaintiffs and other legal heirs of the deceased Dr. Ahmadulla Khan have divided the properties of Dr. Ahmadulla Khan and the suit schedule property fallen to the share of the plaintiffs.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 16. It is further defence of the defendant that he has disputed the title of the plaintiffs over the suit schedule propert, hence, the suit for eviction without seeking the relief of declaration is not maintainable.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 17.  Where a tenant with full knowledge of the fats, either expressly or in writing or impliedly by acts, such as the payment of rent, attorns tenant to a person other than his original landlord or one who is claiming the estate of interest of such original landlord by assignment, succession, or othewise, he is ordinarily estopped from questioning the title of the person to whom he has so attorned.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under Section 116 of the Indian Evidence Act, the tenant is estopped from questioning the title of the landlord.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence, the defendant is precluded from question title of the landlord on the general principles of estoppel between landlord and tenant.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence, the defence of the defendant is not maintainable.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 18. The defendant in his cross-examination has admitted that he stopped paying rent from June 2000.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Admittedly, the original landlord Dr. Ahmedulla Khan died in the year 2005.
label: ANALYSIS

text: But the defendant has not put forward his steps to deposit the rent before the Court and to pay the rent to Dr. Ahmedulla Khan.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The very act of the defendant itself shows that he is making false claim.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The acts of the plaintiffs by adducing oral and documentary evidence have established their case that, they are the absolute owners of the suit schedule property, by virtue of Partition deed dt.5-4-2006 and defendant is tenant under them.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly, I answer Issue Nos.1 & 2 in the affirmative.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 19. ISSUE NO.3:-
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Issue is framed with respect to termination of tenancy by issuing legal notice.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs have asserted that the notice dt.16-10-2009 issued to the defendant terminating the tenancy on 31-10-2009 is valid under law.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Of- course, there is no dispute with regard to issuance of such notice in favour of the defendant and the defendant has given reply to the said notice.
label: ANALYSIS

text: While answering Issues-1 & 2 have concluded that the plaintiffs are the absolute owners of the suit schedule property and defendant is tenant under them.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Said notice was issued on 16-9-2009 which is marked at Ex.P-24 which was served on the defendant on 22-9-2009.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The acknowledgement for the same is marked as Ex.P-25 and the defendant has also issued reply dt.15-10-2009 as per Ex.P-26.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff has called upon the defendant to vacate the deliver vacant possession by the end of tenancy month 31-10-2009.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The plaintiff in the notice has clearly stated that the tenancy was terminated by the end of 31-10-2009.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter, plaintiffs have waited for more than 15 days to file this suit.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, the said notice is in consolance with the provisions of S.106 of the Transfer of Property Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly, I hold that the notice dt.16-09-2009 is valid under law and I answer Issue No.3 in the affirmative.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 20. ISSUE NO.4:-
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Issue is framed with respect to arrears of rent of Rs.4,29,900/- by the defendant.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though the defendant admitted that he stopped paying rent from June 2000, it is not the case of the plaintiffs that they have issued attornment notice to the defendant after property fallen to their share under the Partition deed dt.5-4-2006.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Plaintiffs have further contended that they have informed the defendant during September 2008 that they have acquired the property in their name, but no document is produced by the plaintiffs to show that they have issued attornment notice to the defendant.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence, in my opinion, the plaintiffs are not entitled for the arrears of rent till the tenancy is terminated.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, I hold that the defendant is liable to pay arrears of rent only from the date of termination of tenancy.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Accordingly, Issue-4 is answered in the negative.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 21. ISSUE NO.5:-
label: ANALYSIS

text: This Issue is framed with respect to entitlement of the plaintiffs for vacant possession of the suit schedule property from the defendant with damages.
label: ANALYSIS

text: While answering Issues-1 & 2, I have concluded that plaintiffs are the absolute owners of the suit schedule property and defendant is tenant under them.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Hence, the plaintiffs are entitled for vacant possession of the suit schedule property.
label: RATIO

text: Plaintiffs have also claimed damages from the date of termination of tenancy as defendant is in unauthorised occupation of the suit schedule property.
label: RATIO

text: The remedy of the plaintiffs is to seek damages or mesne profits from the date of termination till possession.
label: RATIO

text: At present, there is no evidence to ascertain the damages.
label: RATIO

text: Hence, Court shall order to make a separate enquiry to ascertain the damages.
label: RATIO

text: Accordingly, Issue-5 is answered partly in the affirmative.
label: RATIO

text: 22. ISSUE NO.6:-
label: RPC

text: In view of above discussion and conclusion arrive at Issues-1 to 5, I proceed to pass the following:- :: O R D E R ::
label: RPC

text: The suit of the plaintiffs is partly decreed.
label: RPC

text: The defendant is hereby directed to vacate and hand over vacant possession of the suit schedule property to the plaintiffs within three months from the date of this judgment.
label: RPC

text: The suit of the plaintiffs for recovery of arrears of rent is hereby dismissed.
label: RPC

text: There shall be a separate enquiry under Or.20 Rule 12 of C.P.C. to ascertain damages or mesne profits.
label: RPC

text: Parties to bear their own costs.
label: RPC

text: Draw decree accordingly.
label: RPC

ACT:
Penal Code 1860 (45 of 1860)--S. 403--Dishonest
misappropriation for a time only is misappropriation.
label: PREAMBLE

text: Prevention
label: PREAMBLE

text: of Corruption Act (2 of 1947)--S.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
5A--Investigation conducted in breach of section--Illegality
must result in miscarriage of justice.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act, 1942--Sub-section (1)
and (2) of s. 23--Bar of prosecution applies only to any
thing done in good faith or "under" the Act.
label: PREAMBLE

text: HEADNOTE:
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The appellants entrusted with the duties of carrying out
improvement schemes under the Bombay Land Improvement Scheme
Act, 1942, were charged with the offence of preparing false
documents and committing criminal breach of trust in respect
of certain amount.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
It was alleged that even though no work
had been done and no amount had been disbursed they prepared
documents 'showing the doing of the work and payment of the
amount, They were convicted under s. 218 read with section
34, section 477A read with section 34 and section 409 read.
with section 34 of the Indian Penal Code as well as section
5(2).
label: PREAMBLE

text:
read with section 5(1)(d) of the Prevention, of
Corruption Act.
label: PREAMBLE

text: The High Court affirmed the conviction.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
in
the appeal to this Court it was contended that after the
matter had been reported to the, higher authorities the
rectification work was done and the money was disbursed for
the purpose for which it had been entrusted; that the
conviction was bad because of non-compliance with section 5A
of the Prevention of Corruption Act; and that the
prosecution was barred by time under s. 23 of the Bombay
Land Improvement Schemes Act, 1942.
Dismissing the appeal
label: PREAMBLE

text:
,
HELD : (i) There is no cogent ground to disagree with the
trial court and the High Court that the accused had prepared
label: PREAMBLE

text:
false documents, bad also committed criminal breach of trust
and were in the discharge, of their duties guilty of
criminal misconduct as defined in s. 5 of the Prevention of

Corruption Act.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
(ii)It is no answer to a charge of criminal
misappropriation that after the matter bad been reported to
the higher authorities the accused got
label: PREAMBLE

text:
the rectification
work done or the money was subsequently disbursed for the
purpose for which it had been entrusted.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
According to
explanation 1 to section 403 Indian Penal Code
label: PREAMBLE

text:
a dishonest
misappropriation for a time only is "misappropriation"
within the meaning of that section.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
(iii)It is well established that cognizance of a case,
has, in fact, been taken by the court on a police report
following investigation conducted in breach of provisions of
section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act, the result
of the trial cannot be set aside unless the illegality in
theinvestigation can be shown to have brought about a
miscarriage of justice.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The reason for the above dictum is
that an illegality committed during the course of
investigation does not effect the competence and
jurisdiction of the Court to, try the accused.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
Where,
therefore, the trial of the case has proceeded to
termination, the invalidity of the preceding investigation
would not vitiate the conviction of the accused as a result
of the trial unless the illegality in the investigation has
caused prejudice to the accused.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
Since there has been no
miscarriage of justice in the present case because of the
alleged non-compliance with section 5A the conviction of the
appellants cannot be set aside on that score.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
[515 H]
H.N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi,
[1955] 1 S.C.R. 1150, referred to.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
(iv)Sub-section (i) of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes
Act 1942 has plainly no application as it relates to anyth
ing done in the good faith.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
It cannot also be said
that the acts of the appellants in preparing false documents
and committing criminal breach of trust as also the act of
criminal misconduct were done "under" the Bombay Land
Improvement Schemes' Act within the meaning of sub-section
(2).
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The subsection has no application where something is
done not under the Act even though it has been done by a
public servant who has been entrusted with the duties of
carrying improvement schemes under this Act.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The impugned
acts of the appellants was not in discharge of their duties
under the Act but in obvious breach and flagrant disregard
of their duties.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
[516 G-517 D]

JUDGMENT
label: PREAMBLE

:
CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION: Criminal Appeal No. 105 of 1969.
label: NONE

text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 27, 1969 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 53 and 45 of 1968.
label: NONE

text: V.S. Kotwal, A. G. Ratnaparkhi and Rajiv Shah, for the appellant.
label: NONE

text: R. M. Mehta and B. D. Sharma, for the respondent.
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Khanna, J.
label: NONE

text: This is an appeal by special leave by Khandu Sonu Dhobi and Bhikanrao Rambhau Khairnar against the judgment of the Bombay High Court affirming on appeal the conviction of the appellants under section 218 read with section 34, section 477A read with section 34 and section 409 read with section 34 of Indian Penal Code as well as under section 5 (2) read with section 5 ( 1 ) (d) of the Prevention of Corruption Act.
label: FAC

text: Sentence of rigorous imprisonment for a period of one year and a fine of Rs. 200 or in default further rigorous imprisonment for a period of two months has been awarded on each count to, the appellants..
label: RLC

text: The substantive sentences have ben ordered to run concurrently.
label: RLC

text: Dhobi appellant No. 1 was an agricultural assistant and was working under Khairnar appellant No. 2 who was agriculturalsupervisor in the soil conservation section of the Government of Maharashtra.
label: FAC

text: Dhobi was incharge of the work relating to a Bundh in block No. 13 of village Asane in Taluka Mandurbar.
label: FAC

text: The above block comprises agricultural lands bearing survey Nos. 8, 17, 18, 19 and 32 measuring 90 acres.
label: FAC

text: The Bundhs were being constructed since the year 1962.
label: FAC

text: Rectification work in respect of those Bundhs at a cost of Rs. 369.07 had to be got done by Dhobi appellant under the supervision of Khaimar appellant.
label: FAC

text: The Government sanctioned an amount of Rs. 4779 in connection with the construction of the Bundhs.
label: FAC

text: An advance amount of Rs. 5000 was received by Khaimar accused on March 2, 1966 in that connection.
label: FAC

text: Work of the value, of Rs. 4400 was done but that relating to rectification work was not done.
label: FAC

text: According to the rules of the soil conservation section, the Government spent the money in the first instance and after the report of the completion of work was received, the expenses were recovered from the landowners for whose benefit the work was done.
label: FAC

text: On March 11, 1966 Khaimar made entries in measurement book Ex. 27 showing that he had checked 28 payments and certified the, same.
label: FAC

text: Khaimar accused also stated in the entry that he had passed the measurements and paid Rs. 369.07.
label: FAC

text: Paysheets Ex. 64 were prepared by Dhobi accused and he obtained the thumb impressions and signatures of the laborers on the paysheets.
label: FAC

text: Khaimar made his initials below the thumb impressions in the paysheets.
label: FAC

text:
On the last page of the paysheets, Khaimar signed a certificate according to which he had paid Rs.
369.07 to PW 10 Jagan Trinibak who used to do the labour work.
label: FAC

text: Final bill Ex. 28
label: FAC

text: was also prepared on that day by the accused and the signature of Jagan Trimbak was obtained on the same.
label: FAC

text: The bill was got signed from PW 7 Ziparu Tukaram and another person as attesting witnesses.
label: FAC

text: The bill was signed thereafter by Khaimar.
label: FAC

text: Debit entry Ex. 32 of Rs.
label: FAC

text: was made by Khaimar accused in the cash book.
label: FAC

text: He also prepared work abstract Ex. 29 on April 16, 1966 and sent it to the sub-divisional soil conservation officer Nandurbar showing an expenditure of Rs. 369-07.
label: FAC

text: The case of the prosecution was that the measurement book Ex. 27, paysheets Ex. 64, final bill Ex. 28 and cash book entry Ex. 32 were false documents and were fabricated by the accused without doing any reification work on the Bundh.
label: FAC

text: The accused thus committed criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs. 369.07 in furtherance of their common intention to misappropriate government property.
label: FAC

text: According further to the prosecution case, the landowners in block No. 13 came to know of the, above, acts of the accused and they complained about it to Sarpanch Tanku Bhagwan (PW 12).
label: FAC

text: Tanku sent a telegram on April 12, 1966 to the superintending agricultural officer, Bombay division, Nasik in this connection.
label: FAC

text: A copy of the telegram wasthereafter sent by the superintending agricultural officer to divisional soil conservation officer D.S.D. Ghate (PW 1) for necessary action as well as for enquiry and report.
label: FAC

text: Chate PW went to village Asane on May 2, 1966 and inspected block No. 13.
label: FAC

text: He found that entries had been made about the payment of Rs. 369.07 in the measurement book and cash book even though no rectification work had been done.
label: FAC

text: Chate submitted his report on May 6, 1966 for proceeding departmentally against the accused.
label: FAC

text:
On receipt of the above report, the superintending agricultural officer directed P.
R. Inamdar (PW 1 1 ), deputy director of agricultural engineering, to go to Asane village and submit his report after personally verifying the facts.
label: FAC

text: Inamdar went with Ghate to block No. 13 in Asane village on May 11, 1966.
label: FAC

text: Both Inamdar and Ghate found that no rectification work had been done.
label: FAC

text: They did not find even a single pit in the lands in that block although, according to measurement book, 83 pits had been recently dug.
label: FAC

text: Inamdar and Ghate also met the Sarpanch and other landowners of Asane village.
label: FAC

text: Report dated May 18, 1966 was thereafter submitted by Inamdar affirming those facts.
label: FAC

text: Sarpanch Tanku sent complaint Ex. 84, in the meanwhile, on April 30, 1966 to the director of anti-corruption branch Maharashtra State stating that the accused had prepared false bill for Rs. 369.07 without doing any work and that they had misappropriated that amount.
label: FAC

text: It was also stated that attempts were being made to shield the accused.
label: FAC

text: The director of anti-corruption sent a copy of that application to Sub Inspector K. G. Patil (PW 13) who was then attached to Dhulia officse of the anticorruption branch.
label: FAC

text: Sub Inspector Patil made local enquiry and took into possession the measurement book, paysheets and cash book.
label: FAC

text: The director of anti-corruption branch directed Patil to register a case and investigate into the, matter.
label: FAC

text: Patil went to Nasik and recorded statement Ex. 79 of Inamdar PW on November 7, 1966.
label: FAC

text: The statement was then sent to Nandurbar Taluka police station.
label: FAC

text: A case was registered on the basis of that statement at the police station on November 8, 1966.
label: FAC

text: On November 12, 1966 sub Inspector Patil applied for permission under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act of judicial magistrate 1st class to investigate the offence.
label: FAC

text: The permission was granted by the judicial magistrate 1st class Nandurbar on the same day.
label: FAC

text: Patil thereafter recorded statements of a number of persons.
label: FAC

text: Patil was subsequently transferred and the case was investigated by his successors Mahamuni and Kulkarni who also obtained the requisite permission.
label: FAC

text: Sanction Ex. 97 for the prosecution of the two accused was granted under section 6 of the Prevention of Corruption Act by the superintending agricultural officer Bombay division, Nasik on May 18, 1967.The
label: FAC

text: two accused in their statements admitted that the work of the value of Rs. 369.07 wasnot done till March 11, 1966 although it was so stated in the various documents by them.
label: FAC

text: The accused also admitted that no amounts were paid to any of the labourers mentioned in the paysheets although signatures and thumb impressions of the labourers had been obtained on the paysheets on March 11, 1966.
label: FAC

text: According to the accused, they had prepared the various documents in accordance with the instructions of Ghate PW who was insisting in March 1966, and even earlier, that a completion report relating to block No. 13 be sent as the entire amount spent on that block since 1962 could not be recovered for want of a. completion report
label: FAC

text: . Khaimar accused added that rectification work had been done between May 13, 1966 and May 16, 1966 and the amount of Rs. 369.07 was thereafter disbursed on May 16, 1966.
label: FAC

text: The learned special judge held that the amount of Rs. 369.07 had not been paid by the two accused to the labourers.
label: RLC

text: No work, it was found, had been done and the different documents prepared by the accused in this connection were false even on their own admissions.
label: RLC

text: The explanation furnished by the accused that they prepared false documents at the instance of Ghate and got work done thereafter was not accepted.
label: RLC

text: Objection was raised on behalf of the accused that the investigation of the case was illegal and that prosecution was barred by time under the pro-visions of section 23 of the Land Improvement Schemes Act, 1942.
label: FAC

text: These objections were repelled.
label: FAC

text: The accused were accordingly convicted and sentenced as above.
label: FAC

text: On appeal the High Court affirmed the, findings of the learned special judge.
label: FAC

text: We have heard Mr. Kotwal on behalf of the, appellants and are of the opinion that there is no merit in the appeal.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has not been disrupted before us that the accused made various entries and prepared documents on March 11, 1966 about their having got the rectification work done as well as about the payment of Rs. 369.07 on that account.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has also not been disputed before us that the amount of Rs. 369- 07 was not paid to any one by the accused in March or April 1966.
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to Ghate (PW 1) and Inamdar (PW 11), no work relating to the rectification of the Bundh was found to have been done till May 11, 1966 when they visited the site in question.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Inamdar's evidence also shows that according to the measurement book prepared by the accused, 83 pits had been recently dug although the witness could not find a single pit on the spot.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In view of the above, we find no cogent ground to disagree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused had prepared false documents and had also committed criminal breach of trust in respectof the amount of Rs. 369.07.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We also agree with the trial court and the High Court that the accused were in the discharge of their duties guilty of criminal misconduct as defined in section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mr. Kotwal has argued that the accused completed the recti- fication work after May 11, 1966,.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is, however, no direct evidence as may show that the, rectification work was completed' after May 11, 1966.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if it may be assumed that the accused completed the rectification work in May 1966, that fact, in our opinion, would not absolve the accused of their criminal liability.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The charge, against the accused relates to preparation of false documents because even though no work had been done till March 11, 1966 and no amount had been disbursed, they prepared docu- ments showing the doing of that work and the payment of that amount.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is no answer to, that charge that after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities, the accused in the month of May 1966 got the rectification work done.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is also no answer to a charge of criminal misappropriation that the money was subsequently, after the matter had been reported to the high authorities, disbursed for the purpose for which it had been entrusted.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
According to explanation 1 to section 403 Indian Penal Code, a dishonest misappropriation for a time only is "
misappropriation " within the meaning of that section.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mr. Kotwal has also submitted that the accused expressed willingness to complete the work after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This submission, 'even if accepted, would not exonerate the accused because the willingness after the matter had been reported to the higher authorities could not efface or undo the offence earlier committed by the accused.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Argument has then been advanced on behalf of the appellants that Sub Inspector Patil did not make investigation in the case in accordance with law.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is urged that permission to make investigation was granted to Sub Inspector Patil on November 12, 1966 and, as such, he was not authorized to make before that date the enquiry which led to the registration of the case as that enquiry partook of the character of investigation.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nothing has been brought to our notice as to how an enquiry before the registration of a case can be held to be investigation.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The matter, however, need not be dilated upon and it is not necessary to express any final opinion in the matter because we find that there is no material on the record as may show that the accused were prejudiced because of the alleged non-compliance with the provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is well established that where cxognizance of a case has, in fact, been taken by the court on a police report following investigationconducted in breach of provisions of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act, the result of the trial cannot be set aside unless the illegality in the investigation can be shown to have brought about a miscarriage of justice.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The underlying reason for the above dictum is that an illegality committed in the course of investigation does not affect the competence and jurisdiction of the court to try the accused.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Where, therefore, the trial of the case has proceeded to termination, the invalidity of the proceeding investigation would not vitiate the conviction of the accused as a result of the trial unless the illegality in the investigation has caused prejudice to the accused (see H. N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of DelHi(1)].
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Since there has been no miscarriage of justice in the present case because of the alleged non-compliance with section 5A, the conviction of the accused appellants cannot be set aside on that score.
label: ANALYSIS

text: For the same reason, we are unable to accede to the contention of Mr. Kotwal that the conviction of the accused should be set aside because permission under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act to SI Patil for investigation of the offence was granted in a ,casual manner and without the existence of sufficient reasons.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Lastly, it has been argued by Mr. Kotwal that the prosecution of the accused was barred by time under section 23 of the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes, Act, 1942.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
The section reads as under "(1) No suit, prosecution or other legal proceeding shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done under this Act or the rules made thereunder.
                         (2)No suit or prosecution shall be instituted against any public servant or person duly authorized under this Act in respect of anything done or intended to be done, under this Act, unless the, suit or prosecution has been instituted within six months from the date of the act complained of."
Sub-section (1) of the section has plainly no application as it relates to anything done in good faith.
label: STA

text: According to Bombay General Clauses Act, a thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly, whether it is done negligently or not.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
The appellants admittedly were not acting honestly when they prepared the false documents in question and showed disbursement of Rs.
369.07 on March 11, 1966.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
Mr. Kotwal, however, relies on sub-section (2) of section 23 and (1) [1955] 1 S.C.R. 1150.
 submits that the prosecution could be instituted against the appellants only within six months from March 11, 1966.
label: ANALYSIS

text: As the charge sheet was submitted long after the expire of six months, the case against the accused-appellants, according to the counsel, was barred by time.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This contention, in our opinion, is devoid of force.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sub-section (2) refers to suit or prosecution against a public servant or person duly authorized under the Act in respect of anything done or intended to be done under the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It cannot be said that the acts of the accused-appellants in preparing false documents and in committing criminal breach of trust in respect of the amount of Rs. 369-07 as also their act of criminal misconduct were done under the Bombay Land Improvement Schemes Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Sub- section (2) of section 23 deals with anything done or intended to be done under the above mentioned Act by a public servant or a person duly authorized under the Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has no application where something is done not under the Act even though it has been done by a public servant who has been entrusted with duties of carrying out improvement schemes under the above mentioned Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The impugned acts of the appellants in the present case were not in discharge of their duties under the above mentioned Act but in obvious breach and flagrant disregard of their duties.
label: RATIO

text: Not only they did no rectification work for the Bundh which was a part of the improvement scheme, they also misappropriated the amount which had been entrusted to them for the purpose of rectification.
label: RATIO

text: Prayer has also been made for the reduction of the sentence, but we see no cogent ground to interfere with the same.
label: RPC

text: The appeal consequently fails and is dismissed.
label: RPC

text:
K.B.N.                     Appeal dismissed.

label: NONE

text: This appeal is filed by Accused Nos. 1, 2, 3, 5 and 9 against the judgment of the High Court whereby Guru @ Gurubaran (A1) and Durai @ Durairajan (A2) have been convicted under Section 302, Indian Penal Code (IPC) and sentenced to imprisonment for life and to pay a fine of Rs.1000/ each with default sentence of 3 months rigorous imprisonment (RI).
label: RLC

text: As far as Vettri @ Vetrivell (A3) is concerned
label: RLC

text: , he was convicted under Section 324 IPC on two counts and sentenced to one year RI on each count and fine of Rs.1000/ with default sentence of 3 months.
label: RLC

text: Narayanan (A5) and Srinivasan (A9) along with other accused were convicted under Section 323 IPC and sentenced to undergo six months RI and pay fine of Rs.1000/ each with default sentence of 3 months.
label: RLC

text: All the sentences were to run concurrently.
label: RLC

text: 2. The prosecution case is that Parasuraman (PW14), son of deceased Saroja and Munusamy Pillai (PW1), was in love with Uma, the younger sister of A1.
label: FAC

text: They both got married and after the marriage, PW14 lived in his wife's house.
label: FAC

text: However, Saroja (deceased) did not approve of this.
label: FAC

text: Thereafter, PW14 came back to his house.
label: FAC

text: On 03.03.1998, it is alleged that Jayaraman (A4) assaulted Nagarajan (PW2), brother of Saroja and brotherinlaw of PW1.
label: FAC

text: To settle the dispute, a Panchayat was called the next day.
label: FAC

text: It is admitted that this Panchayat was called at the instance of A1.
label: FAC

text: The Panchayat was to be conducted in the evening.
label: FAC

text: However, since the Pradhan of the Panchayat was indisposed, the Panchayat could not be held.
label: FAC

text: Thereafter, PW2, his sister Saroja (deceased), his wife Rani (PW7), Murugan (PW13) and Naveen Kumar, son of PW2 and PW7 stood outside the house of PW2 talking amongst themselves.
label: FAC

text: According to him, PW13 had come to the village because of the Panchayat.
label: FAC

text: While they were standing there, A1 came armed with a sickle (Koduval), A2 armed with an Iron Pipe, A3 armed with a sickle (Koduval) and A4 to A9 carrying thick wooden staffs in their hands.
label: FAC

text: It is alleged that A1 attacked deceased Saroja with a sickle on the front portion of her head and said that it was only because of her that the younger sister of A1 has to live separately from her husband.
label: FAC

text: A2 gave a blow on the back of the neck of Saroja with an iron pipe.
label: FAC

text: The other accused are alleged to have attacked Saroja with wooden staffs in their hand.
label: FAC

text: When the family members of Saroja tried to protect her, all the 9 accused surrounded her and, as such, they could not protect her.
label: FAC

text: According to the eyewitnesses, they were also attacked by the members of the aggressive party.
label: FAC

text: The version of all the eye witnesses is similar.
label: FAC

text: 3. However, there are some discrepancies with regard to the manner in which the said incident took place.
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to PW 1, on the date of Panchayat, first a verbal altercation took place between the two sides and then the attack took place whereas, according to PW2 and some of the other eyewitnesses, the attack took place without any provocation.
label: FAC

text: We are of the considered view that for the purpose of deciding this appeal, we can even presume that there was some verbal altercation between the two sides.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 4. The occurrence is not denied.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The main defence is that there was a free fight on both sides and that there is no evidence to show that there is prior meeting of minds.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The accused had not been convicted under Section 34 or Section 149 IPC and, therefore, each individual accused can only be convicted for the injury attributed to that individual.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, it becomes relevant to refer to the medical evidence of the autopsy surgeon Dr. Rajamani, Assistant Surgeon (PW3).
label: FAC

text: The injuries are as follows: "1. An Antemortem red, oblique lacerated wound measuring 6cm x 1cm x 1cm, exposing the bones over the left frontal region of scalp, 1 cm away from the midline with bleeding and blood clots.
label: FAC

text: On Exploring the wound, echymosis seen behind the scalp over the frontal, parietal, temporal and back of skull.
label: FAC

text: There is a fracture of frontal bone measuring 5 cm in length, vertical, para sagittally and 1cm away from midline over the left side, extended to upwards to fronto parietal junction, and another fracture line which is adjacent to it and slightly oblique from the frontal bone to towards fronto parietal junction, 4cm x 1/8 on and on exposing the skull bones blood clots seen over the membranes of the leftcerebral hemisphere of brain on the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital region, of the brain.
label: FAC

text: Both fractures are involving inner and outer table of the skull.
label: FAC

text: 2.  An abrasions varying size from 3cm to 21/2cm x  cm with  cm different from each other, oblique, placed over middle 1/3 of right side neck.
label: FAC

text: 3.  An AM abrasion 21/2cm x  cm obliquely placed 1cm away from injury No.2 on right side of neck.
label: FAC

text: 4.  An AM swelling whole of the anterior and lateral side of right side neck.
label: FAC

text: On exposing the injury No.2, 3, 4 minor blood clots under the skin of neck and congestion of sternomastoid muscle and blood clots seen in anterior and lateral side of right side neck."
label: FAC

text: 5. The doctor states that these injuries caused the death.
label: FAC

text: The first injury is a lacerated wound and it is urged by Mr. S. Nagamuthu, learned senior counsel, that this injury could not have been caused by sickle (Koduval), which is a sharpedged weapon.
label: FAC

text: A sickle is an instrument mainly meant for cutting grass and crops.
label: FAC

text: The inner side is sharp but the outer side is blunt.
label: FAC

text: While using it as an instrument of agriculture only, the sharp edge is used but while using it as a weapon of offence, more often than not, it will be the outer side which will be used to hit the victim.
label: FAC

text: The doctor has opined that the injury could have been caused by a sickle which is MO1 and, therefore, the medical evidence fully corroborates the version of all the eye witnesses.
label: FAC

text: 6. It was next urged that the offence was not of murder but may amount to culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
label: FAC

text:
It has been urged that the case would fall within Exception 4 to Section 300 IPC, which reads as follows: "Exception 4  Culpable homicide is not murder if it is committed without premeditation in a sudden fight in the heat of passion upon a sudden quarrel and without the offender having taken undue advantage or acted in a cruel or unusual manner."
 7.
label: STA

text: We are of the view that the accused cannot take benefit of this Exception.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It has come in evidence that all the accused persons came armed.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Two were armed with sickles, one with an iron pipe and the other with wooden staffs.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even if it is assumed that they may not have come with the intention of killing, the fact that they were armed, clearly indicates that the occurrence did not take place in the heat of passion, upon a sudden quarrel.
label: ANALYSIS

text: As pointed out above, both sides were coming to attend a Panchayat to settle a dispute.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Where was the need to carry arms if the intention was only to settle a dispute?
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even otherwise, we feel that Exception 4 is not applicable because the manner in which the blow was given right on the middle of the head, brings this case squarely within clause "Fourthly" of Section 300 IPC, which reads as follows: "300. Murder   xxx  xxx  xxx Secondly        xxx  xxx  xxx Thirdly         xxx  xxx  xxx Fourthly  If the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid."
label: STA

text: 8. A1 should have known that the act which he is performing, of hitting the deceased on the head with a sickle with such great force causing fracture of the skull, is so dangerous that it would have imminently caused death.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, we find no reason to alter the sentence or conviction of Guru @ Gurubaran (A1).
label: RATIO

text: 9. However, as far as Durai @ Durairajan (A2) is concerned, since the High Court has held that neither Section 34 nor Section 149 IPC are applicable, each accused will only be responsible for his own acts and injuries.
label: RATIO

text:
In this behalf, reference was made to a judgment of this Court in the case of Atmaram Zingaraji vs.
State of Maharashtra1.
label: RATIO

text: There is no appeal by the State.
label: RATIO

text: As far as A2 is concerned, he is alleged to have given a blow with an iron pipe on the back of the neck of the deceased.
label: RATIO

text: This resulted in injury numbers 2 and 3.
label: RATIO

text: They are merely abrasions and could not have caused death.
label: RATIO

text: Therefore, the accused can only be held guilty of having committed the offence under Section 324 IPC.
label: RATIO

text: He has already undergone imprisonment for around 11 years and, therefore, his conviction under Section 302 IPC is altered to Section 324 IPC and the sentence is reduced to the period of incarceration already undergone.
label: RATIO

text: As far as Vettri @ Vetrivell (A 3), Narayanan (A5) and Srinivasan (A9) are concerned, we find no reason to interfere with the judgment of the High Court as each has been held guilty for the offence which they have committed.
label: RATIO

text: 10. In view of the above, the appeal of Accused Nos. 1, 3, 5 and 9 is dismissed and the appeal of Accused No. 2 is allowed and his 1 (1997) 7 SCC 41 conviction is altered from offence punishable under Section 302 IPC to offence punishable under Section 324 IPC and the sentence is reduced to the period of incarceration already undergone.
label: RPC

text: 11. AccusedAppellant Nos.1 & 2 were granted bail vide this Court's order dated 08.01.2018.
label: RPC

text: In view of the above, bail bond of Appellant No.1 (A1) is cancelled.
label: RPC

text: He shall be taken into custody forthwith to serve remaining period of the sentence and bail bond of Appellant No.2 (A2) is discharged.
label: RPC

text: Pending application(s), if any, stand(s) disposed of.

text: -The only.
label: FAC

text:
question here is about sen.
 tence.
label: FAC

text: The appellant Bed Raj and another, Sri Chand, were jointly charged with the murder of one Pheru.
label: FAC

text: The Sessions Judge convicted Bed Raj under section 304, Indian Penal Code, and sentenced him to three years' rigorous imprisonment.
label: RLC

text: He acquitted Sri Chand.
label: RLC

text: I Bed Raj appealed to the High, Court and that Court, on admitting the appeal for hearing, issued notice to the appellant to show cause why the sentence should not be enhanced.
label: RLC

text: The appeal and the revision were heard together.
label: RLC

text: The appeal was dismissed and the High Court enhanced the sentence to ten years.
label: RLC

text: Now, though no limitation has been placed on the High Court's power to enhance it is nevertheless a judicial act and, like all judicial acts involving an exercise of discretion, must be exercised along, well known judicial lines.
label: FAC

text: The only question before us is whether those lines have been observed in the present case.
label: FAC

text: The facts that have been found by the Sessions Judge and accepted by the High Court are to be found in the opening paragraph of the learned Sessions Judge's judgment.
label: FAC

text: They are as follows: "Roop Chand, the son of Bed Raj accused, was removing the dung.
label: FAC

text: of the bullocks of Pheru deceased from an open space near his cattle shed.
label: FAC

text: Pheru protested to, the boy and turned down the basket in which the boy had put the dung.
label: FAC

text: The two accused who are brothers then came to the scene from their own cattle shed which was near by and there was an exchange of abuses between them and Pheru.
label: FAC

text: The accused Sri Chand then caught hold of Pheru by the waist and Bed Raj accused took out a knife and stabbed him in 3 or 4 places.
label: FAC

text: The knife was then left sticking in the neck of the deceased and the accused ran away".
label: FAC

text: The assault occurred about 8 o'clock on the morning of the 23rd February 1952.
label: FAC

text: Pheru was removed to the hospital and the Medical Officer Dr. Fateh Singh examined him and found that he was suffering from shock.
label: FAC

text: He found three injuries on his person: all "simple".
label: FAC

text: He gave the following description of them: right side lower part.
label: FAC

text: (2) Incised wound: 1 " x 1/3" X1/3" right deltoid region frontal and lower part above downward.
label: FAC

text: (3) Incised wound 1/2" X 1/6" X 1/4"Epigastric region".
label: FAC

text: He said- "When Pheru was admitted in the hospital he was under shock but his condition was not dangerous
label: FAC

text: . When Pheru came he could speak.
label: FAC

text: He was not unconscious.
label: FAC

text: As he was under shock no report was made for recording his dying declaration.
label: FAC

text: I cannot give the definite cause of death.
label: FAC

text: I cannot tell if sucH an InjurY can cause death.
label: FAC

text: There was no Haemorrhage from Pheru's neck after his arrival in my hospital.
label: FAC

text: Speaking:of the inJurieis, the doctor said- "Injuries 2 and 3 on the person of Pheru which were incised wounds were not punctured.
label: FAC

text: It was not possible to inflict them from a sharp pointed weapon".
label: FAC

text: The appellant was also examined by the doctor and a slight simple injury, which could have; been caused by a simple blunt weapon, was discovered.
label: FAC

text: This indicates that there was a scuffle between the appellant and the deceased, in which the appellant was hit over the nose and, up to a point, bears out what the appellant says in his defence, namely that Pheru was beating the appellant's son Rup Chand; he went there and tried to extricate Rup Chand; Pheru started beating him (the appellant) and he, the appellant, received a flat blow on the nose.
label: FAC

text: The depth of the injury on Pheru's neck was I of an inch.
label: FAC

text: In this connection the doctor says- "A knife can penetrate 1 1/2 or 2 inches in a case of deliberate stabbing".
label: FAC

text: Pheru died about 12-45 A.M. on the 24th February 1952, that is to say, about 16 or 17 hours after the assault.
label: FAC

text:
The post-mortem was conducted by another doctor, Dr. J. K.
Dwivedi.
label: FAC

text:
Describing the injury on the neck-the only one we need consider as the other two were slight-he said that clotted blood was present all round injury No, 1, and, that--"the:right side dome of pleura is punctured under injury No.
1 and clotted blood present all round it.
label: FAC

text: Upper lobe of right lung (appex) is punctured for 1/4" X 1/4" X 1/2".
label: FAC

text: Clotted blood present over the lung surface all round the punctured area.
label: FAC

text: A branch of the external jugular vein was divided in right side neck under injury No. I.
label: FAC

text: Death was due to shock, and haemorrhage as a result of injury to neck".
label: FAC

text: In cross-examination he said- "It was possible and impossible also that the bleeding could be stopped.
label: FAC

text: Such injury as injury No. I are more likely to cause death".
label: FAC

text: After reviewing the evidence 'the learned Sessions Judge held- "It is evident that the whole scene took just a few moments.
label: RLC

text: Both of the accused must have been in a moment of heat and before either of them could think of doing any act, the whole thing was over........
label: RLC

text: That the injuries with the knife were likely to cause death is clear but they were caused at a time when the parties were in a heat and there was a sudden fight and no room for premeditation".
label: RLC

text: Because of this, and seeing that there was no reason to infer pre-concert, he acquitted the other accused, and by reason of those circumstances he considered that three years would be sufficient punishment and sentenced the appellant accordingly.
label: RLC

text: This was on 17-11-1952.
label: FAC

text: The appellant filed an appeal to the High Court on 1.8-12- 1952 and that Court thereupon issued notice to him to show cause why the sentence I should not be enhanced.
label: FAC

text: The High Court directed enhancement on 7-1-1954.
label: FAC

text:
On the same day the State Government ordered the release of the appellant on probation, under section 2 of the U.P.
Prisoners' Release on Probation Act, 1938, for the full term of the sentence imposed by the Sessions Court.
label: FAC

text: We are not concerned with the State Government's order except in so far' as it indicates the view that that Government took of the antecedents and conduct in prison of the appellant, matters that are also relevant for consideration by a Courtwhen determining a, question of sentence-' a prisoner can only be released on probation under that Act if the State Government is satisfied "from his antecedents and his conduct in the prison that he is likely to abstain from crime and lead a peaceable life, if he is released from prison".
label: ANALYSIS

text: These facts were not known to the High Court when it made its order of enhancement' but it is a matter relevant for our consideration now that the appeal is before us.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Now the High Court accept the findings of the Sessions Judge about the circumstances in which the offence took place.
label: ANALYSIS

text: They agree that the attack was not premeditated and that there was a sudden quarrel and that the blows were inflicted in the heat of passion,.
label: ANALYSIS

text: They also say that there was counter-abuse and they notice the abrasion on the appellant's nose.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Despite this they hold-that' "it is possible that this injury was received by the appellant in the attempt of the deceased to resist the attack made by the appellant.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There was therefore no fight'.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is a very half-hearted finding and ignores the fact that the benefit of all doubts must be given to the accused.
label: ANALYSIS

text: If it was only "possible" that the injury was due to Pheru's attempt to ward off an attack by the appellant, then it must be equally "possible" that it was received in the course of a, scuffle.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant very definitely says in his examination that there was a fight and the abrasion on his nose which the doctor says was caused by a blunt weapon, bears out his version that Pheru struck him with his fist.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The circumstances also indicate that there must have been a scuffle.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why else should it be necessary for the second accused to come and hold him down by the waist?
label: ANALYSIS

text: When villagers or any man for that matter, come to blows after hot words and an interchange of abuse, there is nearly always resistance to the initial attack.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Very rarely does a man "turn the other cheek".
label: ANALYSIS

text: It must also be remembered that the incident started with the use of force by Pheru.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was he who took hold of the basket of cow dung andoverturned it.
label: ANALYSIS

text: That occasioned the quarrel, and the finding is that there was abuse and counter-abuse.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It was then that the second accused rushed in and caught Pheru by the waist.
label: ANALYSIS

text: That accused was acquitted because there was nothing to suggest that that was done in aid of the appellant's intention to-assault Pheru and he -was absolved of all intention to assault on his own account; and the finding is that even the appellant had no such intention till the last moment.
label: ANALYSIS

text: If that was the case, then why should the second accused rush in and hold Pheru by the waist?
label: ANALYSIS

text: If he had no intention to assault on his own account and none to assist the appellant in his assault, the only other reasonable conclusion is that he tried to stop a fight.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It would be fair in the circumstances to reach that conclusion, for the accused is as much entitled to the benefit of any doubt when a co-accused is acquitted as in any other case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In any case, it was incumbent on the High Court to reach a more definite finding than the one given before -deciding to enhance the sentence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only reason that the learned Judges give is that Pheru was unarmed and as the attack was made with a knife it cannot be said that the appellant did not act in a cruel or unusual manner.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Nevertheless, they uphold the finding that the offence falls under section 304, Indian Penal Code, and not under section 302.
label: ANALYSIS

text: A question of a sentence is a matter of discretion and it is well settled that when discretion has been properly exercised along accepted judicial lines, an appellate court should not interfere to the detriment of an accused person except for very strong reasons which must be disclosed on the face of the judgment; see for example the observations in Dalip Singh v. State of Punjab(1) and Nar Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh (2).
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In a matter of enhancement there should not be interference when the sentence passed imposes substantial punishment.
label: RATIO

text: Interference is only called for when it is manifestly inadequate.
label: RATIO

text: In our opinion, these principles have not been observed.
label: RATIO

text:
It is (1) [1954] S.C.R. 145, 156.
(2) [1955] 1 S.C.R. 238, 241,impossible to hold in'the circumstances described that the Sessions Judge did not impose a substantial, sentence, and no adequate reason has been assigned by the learned High Court Judges for considering the sentence, manifestly inadequate.
label: RATIO

text: In the circumstances, bearing all the considerations of this case in mind, we are of opinion that the appeal (which is limited to the question of sentence) should be allowed and that the sentence imposed by the High Court should be set aside and that of the Sessions Court restored.
label: RPC

text: Ordered accordingly.
label: RPC

text: 4. PW1 filed a complaint on 31.10.2004 at 9.45 a.m., in which he stated that his nephew Arun was earlier studying in an engineering college at Chennai.
label: FAC

text: However, he was not studying properly and had developed some bad habits and, therefore, he was shifted to a college at Thoothukudi.

text: The relevant portion of the complaint is to the effect that on 31.10.2004 at about 7.30 a.m. he had received a call from Iqbal (PW2) informing him that his nephew Arun, who stayed the night in Room No.203 of Meena Guest House had consumed heavy dose of a drug through injection and is unconscious.
label: FAC

text: He immediately went to the guest house where he found that his nephew was dead.
label: FAC

label: FAC

text: 5. On the basis of the aforesaid report a case being Crime No.1150 of 2004, was registered.
label: FAC
