label: FAC

text: Dr. A.N. Shanmugham (PW6) conducted the postmortem.
label: FAC

text: He stated that he could not say with certainty what was the cause of death but it was possible by drug injection.
label: FAC

text: Venki was arrested in connection with the said crime and he allegedly made a confessional statement to the police on 08.11.2004 which led to the discovery of Tidijesic syringe, empty ampoules, unused Tidijesic ampoule etc..
label: FAC

text: PW1, the maternal uncle of the deceased, filed a petition in the High Court of Madras in February, 2005 seeking transfer of the investigation to some other agency since he was not happy with the manner in which the case was being investigated.
label: FAC

text: The High Court vide order dated 28.02.2005 transferred the investigation to the CB CID, Tamil Nadu.
label: FAC

text: There were three suspects before the police viz., Venkatesh @ Venki, Sivaprakash @ Siva and Chandrasekaran @ Chandru.
label: FAC

text: All three were subjected to Polygraph, Brainmapping and Narcoanalysis tests at a Forensic Science Laboratory.
label: FAC

text: According to the Investigating Officer (DW4), who carried the investigation, the two appellants herein cleared the said tests and there was no suspicion against them since they disclosed no signs of deception.
label: FAC

text: However, during the tests, Venki's answers were found deceptive.
label: FAC

text: 6. In the year 2006, PW5, father of the deceased, filed a petition in the Madras High Court for transferring the investigation of the case to the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI).
label: FAC

text: This petition was rejected by the High Court on 08.02.2008.
label: FAC

text: Meanwhile, on 23.01.2008, more than three years after the incident, a chargesheet was filed by the CB CID under Section 173 of the Criminal Procedure Code (for short `CrPC') only against Venkatesh @ Venki under Section 304 Part II of the Indian Penal Code (for short `IPC').
label: FAC

text: The present accused (appellants herein) were cited as prosecution witnesses in the said chargesheet.
label: FAC

text:
Venki died after the filing of the chargesheet but before trial of the case on 21.07.2008.
 7.
label: FAC

text: It was only thereafter that PW1, maternal uncle of the deceased, filed a private complaint before the court which is Exhibit P1.
label: FAC

text: In this complaint it was stated that the two accused and the deceased had stayed in Room No. 203 and Venki came to the room at the invitation of the accused Chandru.
label: FAC

text: Venki was a drug peddler and Arun was not in the habit of taking drugs.
label: FAC

text: On the request of the accused, Venki had injected 4 ml of Tidijesic injection in the left wrist of the deceased.
label: FAC

text: It was also alleged that Venki was paid Rs.50/ by the accused Siva for his services.
label: FAC

text: According to this complaint, Arun had been injected for the second time in the left arm inner portion.
label: FAC

text: When this witness went to the room No. 203, Venki was present and told the complainant that the accused had given excess narcotic drugs on the left inner portion of the arm due to which the deceased died.
label: FAC

text: In the complaint it was also stated that immediately after he had visited the guest house on 31.10.2004, he had gone to the Triplicane Police Station, where the police forcibly obtained his signatures on two blank papers.
label: FAC

text: It was alleged that the FIR was lodged by the police in connivance with the two accused.
label: FAC

text: In this complaint it is also mentioned that there were marks of injecting two injections and, according to the report of the Forensic Science Laboratory, a huge amount of narcotic substance had been injected into the deceased which caused his death.
label: FAC

text: In this complaint it was also alleged that the accused Siva had close association with PW10 (hereinafter referred to as `R').
label: FAC

text: According to the complainant, R (PW10) was introduced to the deceased Arun and they used to regularly talk to each other on phone every day and therefore, accused Siva could not tolerate that his girlfriend should shift loyalty to some other person.
label: FAC

text: Therefore, he approached Chandru, who was a student in a medical college and with his help injected excess dose of Tidijesic with the intention of killing Arun.
label: FAC

text: 8. After the filing of the private complaint, the metropolitan magistrate recorded the statements of seven witnesses and found sufficient grounds for proceeding with the case under Section 302 IPC.
label: FAC

text: Thereafter, the case was committed to the Court of Sessions and charges were framed against the accused, who pleaded not guilty.
label: FAC

text: The evidence of the witnesses were recorded.
label: FAC

text: Accused also examined four witnesses.
label: FAC

text: The trial court convicted the accused for having committed the offence punishable under Section 302 IPC read with Section 120B IPC and sentenced them to undergo life imprisonment.
label: RLC

text: Aggrieved, the accused filed two separate criminal appeals, which have been dismissed.
label: FAC

text: Hence, the present appeals.
label: FAC

text: 9. Admittedly, there are no eyewitnesses to the case and this is a case based on circumstantial evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The law with regard to appreciation of circumstantial evidence has been clearly enunciated in the case of Hanumant v. State of Madhya Pradesh1, wherein this Court held as follows: "10......It is well to remember that in cases where the evidence is of a circumstantial nature, the circumstances from which the conclusion of guilt is to be drawn should in the first instance be fully established, and all the facts so established should be consistent only with the hypothesis of the guilt of the accused.
label: PRE_RELIED

text: Again, the circumstances should be of a conclusive nature and tendency and they should be such as to exclude every hypothesis but the one proposed to be proved.
label: PRE_RELIED

text: In other words, there must be a chain of evidence so far complete as not to leave any reasonable ground for a conclusion consistent with the innocence of the accused and it must be such as to show that within all human probability the act must have been done by the accused."
label: PRE_RELIED

text: 10. This law has been consistently followed and has been repeated in catena of authorities.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not necessary to refer to all the authorities.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
However, we may refer to Sir Alfred Wills book Wills on Circumstantial Evidence (Chapter VI)2, in which he has laid down the following Rules specially to be observed in the case of circumstantial evidence: "RULE 1.  The facts alleged as the basis of any legal inference must be clearly proved, and beyond reasonable doubt connected with the factum probandum............
 1 AIR 1952 SC 343 2 Butterworths, Seventh Edition, Pp 296-329.
 RULE 2.  The burden of proof is always on the party who asserts the existence of any fact which infers legal accountability................
                  RULE 3.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
In all cases, whether of direct or circumstantial evidence, the best evidence must be adduced which the nature of the case admits.........
                  RULE 4.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In order to justify the inference of guilt, the inculpatory facts must be incompatible with the innocence of the accused, and incapable of explanation upon any other reasonable hypothesis than that of his guilt..................
label: ANALYSIS

text: RULE 5.
label: ANALYSIS

text: If there by any reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused, he is entitled as of right to be acquitted."
label: ANALYSIS

text: 11. The law can be summarised in the following terms: 1. The circumstances relied upon by the prosecution which lead to an inference to the guilt of the accused must be proved beyond doubt; 2. The circumstances should unerringly point towards the guilt of the accused; 3. The circumstances should be linked together in such a manner that the cumulative effect of the chain formed by joining the links is so complete that it leads to only one conclusion i.e. the guilt of the accused; 4. That there should be no probability of the crime having been committed by a person other than the accused.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 12. It is in the light of the aforesaid law that we have to consider the evidence and the circumstances relied upon by the courts below.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 13. In a case based on circumstantial evidence it is always better for the courts to deal with each circumstance separately and then link the circumstances which have been proved to arrive at a conclusion.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Unfortunately, in this case, though a reference has been made to some circumstances, the circumstances have not been discussed separately.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, we propose to discuss the various circumstances relied upon by the prosecution: 1.
label: ANALYSIS

text: LAST SEEN TOGETHER
label: ANALYSIS

text: As far as this circumstance is concerned, the same stands proved.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of all that Room No. 203 in Meena Guest House was hired by the two accused and the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Venki came at about 9.30 p.m., but he left at 10.15 p.m. Thereafter the lodge was locked.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, this circumstance is proved.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Though this circumstance is proved, we must also look into the circumstances under which the accused were last seen together with the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case of the prosecution is that it is the accused who took the deceased to the room with the intention of killing him since the accused Siva suspected that R (PW10) was having an affair with the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: However, the manner in which the accused reached Chennai and the guest house in question suggests a total different story.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The maternal uncle of the deceased (PW1) states that one Jeyaraj, an employee of PW5 informed him over the phone at about 6/7 p.m. on 30.10.2004 that the deceased Arun along with his friend Siddharth was coming to stay in the night with PW1 at Chennai.
label: ANALYSIS

text: A few minutes later, PW1 talked to his nephew Arun, who also told him that he would be coming to his uncle's house but did not come.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Siddharth is the son of Gomti Pandian (PW7).
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to her, Siddharth told her that he was going to Chennai along with his friend Arun (deceased) to purchase some clothes.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She was reluctant to send her son with his friend but then she talked to Arun who told her that they would be going to Chennai by bus and convinced her to send Siddharth with him.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She dropped Siddharth at the bus stand.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Later she came to know that her son Siddharth had gone to Chennai along with the deceased Arun and three other persons in a car which had met with an accident.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She was informed about this by Kala Devi (PW8), whose son Mathesh had also travelled in the same car.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus, it is clear that it was Arun (deceased), who convinced Siddharth's mother to send Siddharth with him.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This witness also stated that later her son informed her that the car had met with an accident and, thereafter, he and Mathesh did not proceed to Chennai and returned to their homes.
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW8 states that her son Mathesh had told her that he was going to Coimbatore.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Next morning she received a call from her brother's son.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He told her that the car in which Mathesh was travelling had met with an accident.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She was also told that Mathesh along with his friends Siva, Chandru, Siddharth and Arun came to the house of her brother and thereafter Mathesh returned to home.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus, it is clear that Siddharth and Mathesh were also travelling in the car and they would have also gone to Chennai but for the fact that the car met with an accident.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thereafter, Siddharth and Mathesh did not proceed further and returned to their homes.
label: ANALYSIS

text: As such, it is clear that it was not the accused, who had organised the trip but it was the deceased, who had organised the trip and, therefore, it cannot be said that the accused had taken the deceased to the guest house with the intention of killing him.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This assumption by both the courts below is based on no evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2. MEDICAL EVIDENCE
label: ANALYSIS

text: Medical evidence led in this case clearly indicates that the deceased died due to overdose of Tidijesic.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is not disputed that 4 ml of Tidijesic was injected into the wrist of the deceased by Venki, who administered 2 ml of the same substance into himself and thereafter the deceased died.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of Dr. R. Baskaran (PW11), who is Professor and Head of the Department of Legal and Forensic Medicines, Royapettai Government Hospital, Chennai clearly shows that after chemical analysis it was found that the amount of the offending substance found in the blood of the deceased would be equal to injecting 40 ml of Tidijesic.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, there is no manner of doubt that the deceased died due to overdosing of drug.
label: ANALYSIS

text: PW11 stated that if a 20 ml syringe is used then about 40 ml of Tidijesic could be injected in two attempts.
label: ANALYSIS

text: However, if a 5 ml syringe is used, it would require 810 attempts.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He clearly states that he cannot tell when and how this 40 ml Tidijesic was injected into the body of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also could not state what time the death had occurred.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He also stated that it takes 6 to 24 hours for the drug to take effect and this would further depend upon the quantity of the drug, the physique and the actions of the person injected.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, his statement does not help us with regard to the time of death or with regard to the number of attempts in which the drug was injected into the body of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even in the postmortem report the approximate time of death has not been indicated.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr. A.N. Shanmugham (PW 6), who conducted the postmortem also could not say when the death took place.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr. A.N. Shanmugham (PW6) in his statement had stated that injuries caused by the needle due to injection of medicine were found in fore arm, ankle of front foot, front and middle fore arm.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has been confronted with the post mortem report (PD5), in which there is mention of only two injection marks  one in front of left elbow joint and one in middle of left fore arm.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is clearly mentioned that no other external or internal injuries seen over the body.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has not been able to give a proper explanation why he did not mention other injuries in the postmortem report.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This would mean that the deceased was injected only twice.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is the case of the prosecution that on the first occasion the deceased was injected with 4 ml Tidijesic.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, 36 ml could not have been injected in one go on the next occasion.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The police has not recovered any syringe or other material from the room.
label: ANALYSIS

text: As per the prosecution case, the lodge was locked at about 10.30 p.m..
label: ANALYSIS

text: The next morning the deceased was found dead.
label: ANALYSIS

text: No recoveries of any ampoules or syringe have been made from the accused or at their instance to connect them with the offence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution, by means of the aforesaid medical evidence, has failed to link the accused with the death of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The prosecution has failed to prove the exact time of death of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The deceased was first injected an injection between 9.30 p.m. to 10.00 p.m..
label: ANALYSIS

text: As per doctor, the effect of this could end in about six hours.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, the possibility of the deceased getting up himself in the middle of the night to inject himself cannot be ruled out.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is also the possibility of his calling some other person to inject him with the drug.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even more importantly, the prosecution has failed to prove where the balance 36 ml of drug came from.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Who got this drug and when?
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no evidence that the accused purchased this drug.
label: ANALYSIS

text: No recovery has been made from them and, therefore, we are of the view that though it stands proved that the deceased died due to overdose of drug, the prosecution has miserably failed to link the accused with the death of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3. MOTIVE
label: ANALYSIS

text: The motive put forth is that R (PW10) was close to accused Siva, who introduced her to Arun.
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to the case set up by the prosecution, the two had developed a close relationship and were regularly chatting with each other on phone and through SMSes.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was not liked by Siva (Accused No.1), who thereafter conspired with Chandru (Accused No. 2) to kill the deceased by overdosing him.
label: ANALYSIS

text: R (PW10) in her statement has not at all supported the prosecution case and according to her, she had never met Arun but had talked to him over phone and that too occasionally.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She also stated that she and the deceased Arun would exchange SMSes which were usual in nature.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She, in crossexamination, denied the suggestion that she used to talk to Arun every day.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She stated that they talked generally about matters relating to college.
label: ANALYSIS

text: She also denied that she had any special relationship with Siva.
label: ANALYSIS

text: According to her, Siva was her friend being a collegemate.
label: ANALYSIS

text: No other evidence has been led to prove that R (PW10) had any special relationship with accused Siva or that she had developed any special relationship with deceased Arun.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The only evidence in this regard is the statement of R (PW10), which does not support the prosecution case at all.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In this regard, it would also be pertinent to mention that in the first complaint filed by PW1, there is no mention of R (PW10), much less of her having any affair with either the accused or the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was brought out for the first time only in the complaint filed four years after the death of Arun.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no explanation for this long silence of four years.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, we are clearly of the view that the motive has not been proved.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We must also remember that the accused and the deceased were good friends.
label: ANALYSIS

text: They had studied for many years together and there is not even an iota of evidence about such love triangle.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 4. CHANDRU WAS A MEDICAL STUDENT
label: ANALYSIS

text: Both the courts below have come to the conclusion that Chandru was asked by Siva to commit the crime because Chandru was a medical student and he alone knew how to inject the substance into the body of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are constrained to observe that the inference drawn by the courts below was totally ill founded.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Why would Chandru kill another human being just on the asking of the accused Siva?
label: ANALYSIS

text: Chandru was a medical student, studying in a profession meant to save lives and not to kill people.
label: ANALYSIS

text: From the evidence on record it stands established that the deceased was a drug addict and had been taking injectible drugs for a long time.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is well known that such drug addicts can easily inject themselves.
label: ANALYSIS

text: What has happened in this case is not clear but it cannot be said with certainty that Chandru had injected the poisonous substance into the body of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no evidence in this regard.
label: ANALYSIS

text: As we have discussed above, it was not only Siva and Chandru who were coming to Chennai with deceased Arun but Siddharth and Mathesh were also coming to Chennai in the same car.
label: ANALYSIS

text: However, they went back only after the car met with an accident.
label: ANALYSIS

text: All these boys were in their late teens or early 20s and two of them got scared after the accident and they went to the homes of their relatives and from there they contacted their respective mothers.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Since they had obtained permission of their mothers by giving false excuses, they got scared and went back.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even as per the prosecution, Chandru had no motive to kill Arun.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, the inference drawn by the High Court as well as the trial court that Siva and Chandru had conspired or had the common intention of murdering Arun is not based on any cogent or reliable evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 14. Other than the circumstances referred to above, there are other circumstances which go against the prosecution which we shall refer to now: 1. Inconsistency in the statement of PW1  PW1 is the maternal uncle of the deceased.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In his first complaint made in the police station on 31.10.2004, there is no reference to R (PW10) or other facts which have been stated at a later stage.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The private complaint filed by him four years later is contrary to the first complaint filed by him immediately after the occurrence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: His explanation is that he was asked to sign on two blank papers by the police.
label: ANALYSIS

text: First of all, we see no reason why the police in a case of this nature would try to help the accused and shield the actual criminal.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Secondly, there is no material on record to show that PW1, the maternal uncle or PW 5, father of the deceased, ever complained to any authority that PW1 had been forced to sign two blank papers.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This is a case where the maternal uncle and the father of the deceased had approached the High Court on at least two occasions for transfer of the investigation.
label: ANALYSIS

text: They succeeded once and failed on the second occasion.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In case the version of PW1 that his signatures were taken on blank papers was correct, then he would have definitely said so much earlier.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He would have reported the matter to the higher authorities or made mention of this in the petitions filed in the High Court.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Despite a pointed query to the counsel for the original complainant and the informant and the State they failed to point out whether any such complaint had been made by PW1 or PW5.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, we do not accept the version of PW1 that his signatures were obtained on blank sheets of papers.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This also casts a doubt on the veracity of the statement of PW1.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 2. Delay in filing the private complaint
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is true that PW1 and PW5 were moving the High Court for transfer of the case to some other investigating agency but, at the same time, it would be pertinent to mention that after the chargesheet was filed against Venki by the Investigating Officer (DW4), neither PW1 nor PW5 filed any protest petition to the effect that the accused (appellants herein) should also be arraigned as accused.
label: ANALYSIS

text: They let the matter go on and it was only after Venki died that the private complaint was filed.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no explanation why no protest petition was filed when the police had only made out a case against accused Venki and that too under Section 304 IPC and not murder.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 3. PW1 and PW5 are not coming to the Court with clean hands
label: ANALYSIS

text: The motive has been introduced after four years.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The father and the maternal uncle of the deceased never brought up the issue of the deceased having conversations with R (PW10) at any earlier stage.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, PW1 and PW5 are not coming to the court with clean hands.
label: ANALYSIS

text: They have cooked up the story of signing on blank papers and also cooked up the story relating to the motive.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Therefore, their evidence is not reliable and a person cannot be convicted on the basis of such evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 15. All that is proved is that the deceased and the accused were sleeping in one room and the deceased died due to overdose of drug.
label: RATIO

text: The prosecution had miserably failed to prove that the accused injected this drug.
label: RATIO

text: It is the case of the prosecution that the first injection was administered by Venki, which was only 4 ml.
label: RATIO

text: There is possibility of the deceased injecting himself on the second occasion sometime in the middle of the night or early in the morning.
label: RATIO

text: In this context, we must remember that the doctor, who conducted the postmortem has not given any approximate time of death of the deceased which could have helped us in the matter.
label: RATIO

text: The circumstances proved cannot lead to the inference that it is the accused alone who committed the offence.
label: RATIO

text: In fact, the prosecution has even failed to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the death is homicidal in view of the inconsistencies in the medical evidence dealt by us above.
label: RATIO

text: Even otherwise, it is not proved that it was the accused who injected the deceased and the possibility of the accused injecting himself or some other person doing so cannot be ruled out.
label: RATIO

text: 16. In view of the above discussion we allow both the appeals, set aside the judgment dated 30.11.2010 of the High Court in Criminal Appeal No.592 of 2010 and 636 of 2010 and judgment dated 24.09.2010 of the Additional District and Sessions Judge, Fast Track Court No.V, Chennai in S.C. No.237 of 2009.
label: RPC

text: The accusedappellants are acquitted.
label: RPC

text: They are directed to be released immediately unless required in any other case.
label: RPC

text: Pending application(s), if any, stand(s) disposed of.
label: RPC

SUBHASH & ANOTHER

ACT:
         Code of Criminal Procedure, S. 374-Reference for

confirmation of death sentence, whether High Court obliged
to examine entire evidence independently.

HEADNOTE:
         Ram Sanehi received two gun-shot wounds on his chest,

and died within ten minutes.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
Two of his children claimed to
have witnessed the occurrence.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The dead body was subjected
to post-mortem only after about 24 hours had elapsed.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The
same evening, appellant Subhash surrendered, and appellant
Shyam Narain was arrested, though for another offence
altogether.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The Sessions Court convicted them under s. 302
I.P.C. and sentenced Subhash to death and Shyam Narain to
imprisonment for life.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The accused moved the High Court in
appeal, while the Sessions Court referred the matter to it
under s. 374, for confirmation of the death-sentence.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The question before this Court was, whether in the case
of such references, the High Court was obliged to examine
the entire evidence independently.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
Allowing the appeal, the Court,
^

         HELD:
label: PREAMBLE

text:
On a reference for confirmation of the sentence
of death, the High Court is under an obligation to proceed
in accordance with the provisions of sections 375 and 376 of
the Criminal Procedure Code.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
The High Court must not only
see whether the other order passed by the Sessions Court is
correct but it is under an obligation to examine the entire
evidence for itself, apart from and independently of the
Sessions Court's appraisal and assessment of that evidence.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
[589A-B]

         Jumman and Ors. v. The State of Punjab AIR 1957 S.C.
460; Ram Shanker Singh and Ors. v. State of West Bengal
[1962] Supp. 1 SCR 49 at 59 and Bhupendra Singh v. The
State of Punjab [1968] 3 SCR 404, followed.
label: PREAMBLE

text: JUDGMENT:
label: PREAMBLE

text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION:
label: NONE

text: Criminal Appeal No.
label: NONE

text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated 27-11-74 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 2646/73 and Referred No. 95/73.
label: NONE

text: Frank Anthony, E.C. Agarwala and A. T. M. Sampath; for the Appellants.
label: NONE

text: O.P. Rana; for the Respondent.
label: NONE

text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by CHANDRACHUD, J.
label: NONE

text: The appellants, Subhash and Shyam Narain, were convicted by the learned Civil and Sessions Judge, Farrukhabad under section 302 of the Penal Code on the charge that at about 9 a.m. on June 9, 1972 they committed the murder of one Ram Sanehi.
label: RLC

text: Subhash was sentenced to death and Shyam Narain to imprisonment for life.
label: RLC

text: The judgment of the trial court having been confirmed in appeal by the High Court of Allahabad, the two accused have filed this appeal by special leave of this Court.
label: RLC

text: The case of the prosecution is briefly as follows: on the morning of June 9, 1972 the deceased Ram Sanehi had gone to his field along with his son Bal Kishore and his daughter Kusuma Devi for eating Kharbuzas.
label: FAC

text: While they were returning from the field at about 9 a.m. the appellants, who were lying in wait near a culvert, suddenly accosted Ram Sanehi.
label: FAC

text: The Appeallent Subhash pointed the barred of his gun towards the chest of Ram Sanehi and said that since he, Ram Sanehi, was a witness against him in a complaint filed by Pooran Lal and since he was also doing Pairvi on behalf of Pooran Lal he would not be allowed to remain alive.
label: FAC

text: The appellant Shyam Narain was armed     with a lathi.
label: FAC

text: Bal Kishore and Kusuma Devi pleaded with the appellants to spare their father but Shyam Narain asked Subhash not to delay the matter and finish Ram Sanehi quickly.
label: FAC

text: Subhash thereupon fired three shots from his double-barrelled gun, the last of which misfired.
label: FAC

text: Ram Sanehi fell down, whereupon the appellants dragged him by his legs over a distance of 6 or 7 paces.
label: FAC

text: Bal Kishore and Kusuma Devi then raised an alarm whereupon Brij Bhusan, Shyam Lal Mangali Prasad and Jhabbo Singh Thakur reached the place of occurecnce and challenged the appellants.
label: FAC

text: Before running away, the appellant Subhash told his companion Shyam Narain that he on his own part was going to surrender before a court and that Shyam Narain should make his own arrangements.
label: FAC

text: Ram Sanehi died within about 10 minutes after receiving the injuries.
label: FAC

text: Bal Kishore first went to his house which is at about a distance of 120 yards from the scene of offence.
label: FAC

text: At about 12 o'clock at noon he went to the Kamalgani police station and lodged his First Information Report (Ex. Ka-3).
label: FAC

text:
S.I.
 Vishwanath Sharma who was posted as a 2nd officer at the police station recorded Bal Kishore's complaint.
label: FAC

text: went to the scene of occurrence, prepared the inquest report and handed over the dead body for being sent for post-mortem examination to the District Hospital at Farrukhabad which is about 10 miles away form the village of Kandharpur where the incident took place.
label: FAC

text: S.I Sharma took samples of earth from the place of occurrence an seized a mis fired cartridge which was lying concealed in the folds of the deceased's Dhoti.
label: FAC

text: The Fard in that behalf is Ex. Ka-10 and the site- plan is Ex. Ka-11.
label: FAC

text: The appellant Subhash surrendered before the Additional District Magistrate (Judicial) at Farrukhabad at about 4 p.m. on the very day.
label: FAC

text: The appellant Shyam Narain was arrested at about 2-40 p.m. on the same day under section 122 of the Railway Act for crossing The railines at Fatehgarh.
label: FAC

text: The appellants denied the charge that they had committed the murder- of Ram Sanehi and stated that they were involved in the case due to enmity.
label: ARG_PETITIONER

text: This defence has been rejected both by the Sessions Court and the High Court.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Before referring to the evidence in the case it has to be mentioned that the High Court had before it not only the appeal filed by the accused but also a reference made by the Sessions Court for confirma tion of the capital sentence under section 374 of the Code of CriminalProcedure.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Time and again this Court has pointed out that on a reference for confirmation of the sentence of death, the High Court is under an obligation to proceed in accordance with the provisions of sections 375 and 376 of the Criminal Procedure Code.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Under these sections the High Court must not only see whether the order passed by the Sessions Court is correct but it is under an obligation to examine the entire evidence for itself, apart from and independently of the Sessions Court's appraisal and assessment of that evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
From the long line of decisions which have taken this view it would be enough to refer to the decisions in Jumman and ors. v. The State of Punjab, Ram Shanker Singh & ors. v.
State of West Bengal and Bhupendra Singh v. The State of Punjab.
label: PRE_RELIED

text: The High Court has failed to show due regard to this well-established position in law.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It did not undertake a full and independent examination of the evidence led in the case and it mainly contented itself with finding out whether the Sessions Court had in any manner erred in reaching the conclusion that the charge of murder levelled against the appellants was established beyond a reasonable doubt.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court is right in saying that the main question in the case was whether Bal Kishore and Kusuma Devi who were examined as eye-witnesses were truthful witnesses.
label: ANALYSIS

text: But then it did not subject their evidence to any minute scrutiny.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Impressed overbearingly by the circumstance that the Sessions Court "had the opportunity of observing the demeanour" of the witnesses, the High Court apparenty thought that such an opportunity gave to the Sessions Court's judgment a mystical weight and authority, even though the learned Sessions Judge had not, in his judgment or while recording the evidence, made any special reference to the demeanour of the witnesses.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court accepted the evidence of Ram Sanehi's children by observing that there was no material contradiction ill their evidence and that certain statements in the F.I.R. afforded a guarantee that the two witnesses were present when their father was done to death.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We will now proceed to show how several significant circumstances either escaped the attention of the High Court or were not given their due and rightful importance.
label: ANALYSIS

text: First as to the manner in which S.I. Sharma conducted investigation into the case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The offence took place at about 9 a.m. on June 9 and though the District Hospital at Farrukaabad was just 10 miles away, the dead body was not received at the hospital for nearly 24 hours after the incident had taken place.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The excuse offered by the prosecution that cartman was not willing to take the body at night is utterly flimsy because the Investigating officer could have easily made some alternate arrangement for despatchin the dead body for postmortem examination expeditiously.
label: ANALYSIS

text: With the dead body lying at the scene of offence for nearly 12 hours and thereafter at the police station for another 8 or 9 hours, it was easy enough for the witnesses to mould their statements so as to accord with the nature of injuries.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The lnvestigating Officer did not make any note at all in the General Diary as to which witnesses were examined by him on the date of the occurrence which was obligatory upon him to do under paragraph 44 of the U.P. Police Act.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The time when the investigation was commenced and the time when it was concluded are not mentioned in the case diary.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The time when the Investigating officer reached the village and the time when he returned to the police station are also not noted in the case diary.
label: ANALYSIS

text: S.I. Sharma stated in his evidence that several important facts concerning the investigation were being stated by him in his evidence from memory.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
He reached the scene of offence at about 2-30 p.m.
but it was not until about 6 p.m. that he inspected the site.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The dead body was not removed from the scene of offence till about 9 p.m. and even that is open to grave doubt because the Investigating officer has admitted in his evidence that he was unable to say as to when the dead body was taken way from the spot and whether it was taken directly to the hospital or was detained somewhere on the way.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He was unable to say whether it was right or wrong that the dead body remained in the village till about 4 'O'clock on the morning of the 10th.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Forty or fifty persons had gathered at the scene of offence when the Investigating officer arrived but the record of the case does not show that the statement of any of those persons was ever recorded.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact even the statement of Kusuma Devi was recorded late at night for which the reason is stated to be that her elder sister Pushpa Devi died of shock on the evening of the 9th after hearing of her father's murder.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It may be that Pushpa Devi died on the 9th, but apart from the cause of her death, the statement of Kusuma Devi need not have been held up so long.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are doubtful if the Investigating officer at all knew on the 9th that Pushpa Devi had died.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He has admitted that his knowledge in that behalf was derived from hearsay reports.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The appellant Subhash had surrendered before the Additional District Magistrate, Farrukhabad on the afternoon of the 9th itself while the other appellant Shyam Narain was arrested at Fatehgarh at about 2-40 p.m.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Investigating officer did not even know of these significant developments, though they had taken place just a few miles away from the scene of investigation.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He says that he learnt of the surrender and the arrest of the appellants on the evening of the 12th.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mangali Prasad has been examined by the prosecution as an eye-witness and his name is mentioned in the F.I.R. as one of the four persons who arrived at the scene of offence even before the appellants had run away.
label: ANALYSIS

text: His statement was recorded 11 days later on June 20.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The F.I.R. mentions expressly that the appellants caught hold of the legs of the deceased and started dragging him.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Investigating officer has not stated in the Panchnama of the scene of offence whether the ground was soft or hard or sandy which had great relevance on the allegation that the deceased was dragged over a certain distance.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Finally, it is surprising that the Investigating officer did not think it worthwhile to pay a visit to the field where the deceased is alleged to have gone with his children for eating Kharbuzas.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Indeed he stated that he was not in a position to say if there were Kharbuzas at all in the field, when the occurrence took place.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court has condoned these lapses on the part of the Investigating officer with the observation that he "appears to have been inexperienced and somewhat negligent".
label: ANALYSIS

text: The Investigating officer has stated in his evidence that he had put in 7 years of service.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is difficult to understand on what basis the High Court attributed the lapses on his part to mere inexperience.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We will presently indicate the significance of the various lapses and loopholes in investigation but to say, as the High Court has done, that the Investigating Officer was "somewhat negligent" seems to us in the circumstances a grave euphemism.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We will now proceed to deal with the various circumstances which, in our opinion, render it unsafe to accept the prosecution case.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Dr. S.C. Pandiya who performed the post-mortem examination has described in his evidence the injuries received by Ram Sanehi.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In all he found 7 injuries on the dead body, out of which injuries 1, 3 and 7, injuries 2 and 4, and injuries 5 and 6 are interconnected.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Injury No. 1 is described as a "shot wound" with its entry above the left nipple.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Injury No. 3 is described as multiple rounded abrasions on the left side of the chest.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Injury No. 7 is the wound of exit on the right scapular region, corresponding to injury No. 1.
label: ANALYSIS

text: rnjury No. 2 consists of 8 gunshot wounds of entry below the right nipple while injury No. 4 consists of multiple rounded abrasions above the right nipple.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Injury No. 5 is a gun-shot wound of entry on the back of the left forearm while injury No. 6 is the corresponding wound of exit near the ulnar aspect of the left forearm.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of Dr. Pandiya and the description of the injuries given by him in the post-mortem report tend to show that two different kinds of firearms were used by the assailants of Ram Sanehi.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Injury No. 1 was caused by a bullet and that is clear not only from the description of the injury but from what Dr. Pandiya has stated in his evidence.
label: ANALYSIS

text: He says: "The bullet, which had entered through injury No. 1 went out straight after emerging from injury No. 7".
label: ANALYSIS

text: Injuries Nos. 2 and 5 were caused by pellets.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This shows that whereas injury No. 1 was caused by a firearm in the nature of a rifle, injuries 2 and 5 were caused by an ordinary gun.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The medical evidence thus falsifies the eye- witnesses' account according to which, the appellant Subhash alone was armed with a double-barrelled gun, the other appellant Shyam Narain being armed with a lathi.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The objective inference arising from the nature of injuries received by the deceased has a significant impact on the case of the prosecution, which has been overlooked by both the Sessions Court and the High Court.
label: ANALYSIS

text: While we are on the medical evidence it would be appropriate to mention that there was no tatooing or charring on any of the firearm injuries which, according to the doctor, shows that the firing was done from a distance of more than 4 feet.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the First Information Report Bal Kishore has stated that as soon as he, his father and sister, reached the culvert, Subhash "touching the chest" of Ram Sanehi "with thebarrel of his gun" said that he shall not leave him alive; Shyam Narain thereupon exhorted Subhash not to delay and fire immediately; Subhash then fired three shots in quick succession, one of which mishred.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The trend of the F.I.R. is that Subhash fired the first two shots at Ram Sanehi from a point blank range, in which event indisputably, there would have been tatooing and charring around the injuries.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Bal Kishore has attempted to offer an explanation that what he meant to say in his compaint was that Subhash trained his gun "towards" Ram Sanehi's chest and not "on" his chest.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This explanation is an after thought and in the circumstances difficult to accept.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Thus in another important respect, the medical evidence falsifies the case of the prose cution.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is another aspect of the medical evidence which, though, not as important as the two aspects mentioned above, may also be referred to.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The case of the prosecution is that Ram Sanehi had gone to his Kharbuza field with his son and daughter for eating Kharobuzsas.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is evidence that they did eat Kharbuzas and almost immediately there after they started back for home.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Within less than 5 minutes, Ram Sanehi met with his deat near the culvert.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The post-mortem report shows that Ram Sanehi's stomach was empty which means that the evidence that he had eaten Kharbuzas just a little time before his death is untrue.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Bal Kishore tried to wriggle out of this situation by saying that Ram Sanehi had eaten just a small slice of Kharbuza.
label: ANALYSIS

text:
But even there, Dr.
Pandiya has stated that if the entire slice of Kharbuza was eaten by Ram Sanehi, its remains would be found in the stomach provided there was no vomiting after the gun-shot injuries.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Since Ram Sanehi had not vomited, his large intestines could not have been found to be empty if the story of his children was true.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This last circumstance may at first sight seem trivial but its importance consists in the fact that the visit of Ram Sanehi, along with his children, to the Kharbuza field for the purpose of eating Kharbuzas is the very genesis of the incident which happened on June 9, 1972.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Coupled with the circumstance that the Investigating officer did not even pay a visit to the Kharbuza field, leave alone making a Panchnama thereof, the conclusion is irresistible that the story that the children had accompanied their father to the Kharbuza field lacks a factual basis.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The other circumstances which render the prosecution case suspect are these (1) Ram Sanehi is alleged to have been drageed over 6 or 7 paces by the appellants but not even an abrasion was found on his back or stomach which could be attributed to dragging.
label: ANALYSIS

text: (2) Thirty or forty persons are alleged to have collected at the sence of occurrence but Bal Kishore was not able to mention the name of even one of them and it is common ground that the Investigating officer did not record the statement of any of them.
label: ANALYSIS

text: (3) Jhabboo Singh, Shyam Lal Brij Bhushan and Mangali Prasad reached the scene of offence even before the appellants had fled away but none from amongst the first three was examined by the prosecution.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Mangali Prasad was examined as an eye-witness but he has been concurrently disbelieved by the Sessions Court and the High Court.
label: ANALYSIS

text: (4) Though the motive of the offence is alleged to be that in a complaint filed by Pooran Lal against the appellant Subhash, the deceased Ram Sanehi was cited as a witness, Mangali Prasad's evidence shows that immediately after the firing, Bal Kishore told him that Ram Sanehi was murdered because of the disputes concerning the election to the Pradhanki.
label: ANALYSIS

text: What Bal Kishore told Mangali Prasad immediately after the incident seems more probable because, one Virendrapal had contested that election and the appellant Subhash had defeated him.
label: ANALYSIS

text: When Bal Kishore went to lodge his F.I.R. at the police station he was accompanied by Virendrapal, though an attempt was made to show that Virendrapal was only standing outside the police station and had met-Bal Kishore accidently.
label: ANALYSIS

text: (5) The story of Bal Kishore that after the appellant Subhash fired 2 shots he re-loaded his gun but the re-loaded cartridge misured makes hardly any sense.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Subhash was armed with a double barrelled gun and having fired 2 fatal shots from a close range at his target, it is unlikely that he would re-load the gun and that too with only one cartridge.
label: ANALYSIS

text: And if that cartridge misfired, it is impossible to understand how it could be found concealed in the folds of Ram Sanehi's dhoti.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is only one other aspect of the matter which remains to be considered and since the High Court has placed great reliance thereon, it is necessary to deal with it.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The F.I.R. which lodged at about 12 O'clock at noon on the 9th itself mentions that after Ram Sanehi was murdered, the appellant Subhash told his companion Shyam Narain that he himself was going to surrender before a court and that Shyam Narain should make his own arrangement.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In fact, Subhash did surrender in the court of the Additional District Magistrate, Farrukhabad, at about 4 p.m. on the 9th.
label: ANALYSIS

text: What the High Court has over-looked is that Subhash did not surrender in connection with the murder of Ram Sanehi but he surrendered along with the 13 or 14 other accused against whom Pooran Lal had filed a complaint.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In so far as Shyam Narain is concerned, the High Court is wrong in saying that he managed somehow to get himself arrested.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The evidence of Constable Virendra Singh shows that Shyam Narain was arrested because he was crossing the railway lines and if he was not caught, he would have been run over by the two trains coming from Kanpur and Farrukhabad.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This was hardly any sensible way of making an "arrangement" for himself, as directed by Subhash.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is therefore not as if the statement attributed to Subhash in the F.I.R. is corroborated by subsequent events so as to afford a guarantee to Bal Kishore's presence at the culvert.
label: ANALYSIS

text: We are conscious that the Sessions Court and the High Court have both held that the appellants committed the murder of Ram Sanehi but the weight of the circumstances which we have discussed above is so preponderating that even the concurrent finding cannot be allowed to stand.
label: RATIO

text: In any event, it seems to us impossible to hold that the prosecution has established its case beyond a reasonable doubt.
label: RATIO

text:
We therefore allow this appeal, set aside the order of conviction and sentence recorded by the High Court and the Sessions Court and direct that the appellants shall be set at liberty.
 M.R.                                      Appeal allowed.
label: RPC

text: 2.  The petitioner is aggrieved by the action of the 1st respondent in taking steps to sell of the land and house standing thereon which according to the petitioner is of his ownership and stands in his name.
label: FAC

text:
It is the case of the petitioner that the respondents are seeking to recover tax dues of his father for the block years 1986-96 and considering the explanation to Section 222(1) of the Income Tax Act, that action is without jurisdiction.
 3.  The petitioner's case is as under:- The property was purchased on 3rd December, 1974 when the petitioner was a minor in his name by his father.
label: FAC

text: A house was constructed thereon somewhere in 1979-80.
label: FAC

text: The petitioner was born on 25th October, 1969.

label: FAC

text: 4.  There was a search and seizure operation conducted under Section 132 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 against the petitioner's father on 28th March, 1996.
label: FAC

text: During the search an amount of Rs.9,556/- and jewellery of the value of Rs.1,08,200/- was found.
label: FAC

text: In pursuance of the said search an order under Section 158BC of the Income Tax Act was passed.
label: FAC

text: Pursuant to the said order the petitioner's father Shri John Oomen was treated as a defaulter and the Department has served on the petitioner's father notice of demand treating him as a defaulter under the Income Tax Act.
label: FAC

text: On 5th March, 2002 the 1st respondent issued a I.T.C.P.-16 on petitioner's father attaching the petitioner's property Oomen Villa for tax dues of the petitioner's father.
label: FAC

text: The Respondent No.1 in February, 2007 issued I.T.C.P.17 under Rule 53 of the Second Schedule of the Income Tax Rules 1961 i.e. notice for settling a sale proclamation regarding the petitioner's property.
label: FAC

text: The petitioner on being informed about the sale by his father, by letter of 7th April, 2007 filed his objections before the 1st respondent contending that the action of attaching and further proceedings for auction sale were illegal.
label: FAC

text: According to the petitioner on 22nd August, 2007 the 1st respondent issued a summons under Section 131 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 to the petitioner asking him to appear and produce relevant documents for substantiating the petitioner's claim of ownership.
label: FAC

text: In pursuance of the summons the petitioner appeared and produced the relevant documents.
label: FAC

text: .  By an order of 21st September, 2007 which was received by the petitioner on 11th October, 2007 the petitioner was informed that his objections were rejected and the auction proceedings are being initiated in respect of the attached property to recover the arrears of tax dues.
label: FAC

text: Petitioners contention is that Section 222 of the Income Tax Act would not apply and consequently the action of the respondents is without authority of law.
label: FAC

text: Hence the reliefs as prayed for.

text: .  Reply has been filed by Elsy Mathew, Tax Recovery Officer.

text: 5.  The questions for our consideration are:- 1. Does the purchase in the name of the minor son amount to a transfer within the meaning of the explanation to Section 222(1)?
label: ISSUE

text: 2. If on fact it is found that the house was constructed on the land in the year 1979-80 and stands in the name of the petitioner much before a demand was made on his father for the year 1986-96, whether the petitioner in whose name the house and the property stands was liable and the property and house could be attached and sold.
label: ISSUE

text: 6.  To answer the first quesltion, for our consideration we may gainfully refer to the provisions of Section 222(1) which reads as under:- "222(1) When an assessee is in default or is deemed to be in default in making a payment of tax, the Tax Recovery Officer may draw up under his signature a statement in the prescribed form specifying the amount of arrears due from the assessee (such statement being hereinafter in this Chapter and in the Second Schedule referred to as "certificate") and shall proceed to recover from such assessee the amount specified in the certificate by one or more of the modes mentioned below, in accordance with the rules laid down in the Second Schedule--- (a) attachment and sale of the assesee's movable property.
label: STA

text: (b) attachment and sale of the assesee's immovable property; (c) arrest of the assessee and his detention in prison; (d) appointing a receiver for the management of the assessee's movable and immovable properties.
label: STA

text: Explanation:- For the purposes of this sub-section, the assessee's movable or immovable property shall include any property which has been transferred, directly or indirectly on or after the 1st day of June, 1973, by the assessee to his spouse or minor child or son's wife or son's minor child, otherwise than for adequate consideration, and which is held by, or stands in the name of any of the persons aforesaid; and so far as the movable or immovable property so transferred to his minor child or his son's minor child is concerned, it shall, even after the date of attainment of majority by such minor child or son's minor child, as the case may be, continue to be included in the assessee's movable or immovable property for recovering any arrears due from the assessee in respect of any period prior to such date."
label: STA

text:
.  A perusal of the explanation on which reliance has been placed on behalf of the revenue, would contemplate that the movable or immovable property has been transferred directly or indirectly on or after the 1st day of June, 1973, by the assessee to his spouse or minor child or son's wife or son's minor child, otherwise than for adequate consideration, and which is held by, or stands in the name of any of the persons aforesaid; and so far as the movable or immovable property so transferred to his minor child or his son's minor child is concerned, it shall, even after the date of attainment of majority by such minor child or son's minor child, as the case may be, continue to be included in the assessee's movable or immovable property for recovering any arrears due from the assessee in respect of any period prior to such date.
 .
label: ANALYSIS

text: It would be, therefore, clear that there must be a transfer of property on or after 1st June, 1973 in favour of the minor child.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the instant case as we have noted earlier the property was purchased in the name of the petitioner who was then a minor.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Does purchase in the name of minor amount to a transfer within the meaning of the explanation to Section 222(1).
label: ANALYSIS

text: Transfer is defined for the purpose of capital assets under Section 2(47) of the Income Tax Act and includes sale, exchange or relinquishment of the assets or extinguishment of any right.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The other sub-clauses need not be adverted to.
label: ANALYSIS

text: It is, therefore, clear that the transfer would include  sale, exchange or relinquishment of the assets.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In the instant case the property was purchased in the name of the minor as in law a minor cannot contract.
label: ANALYSIS

text: That purchase was in the year 1974.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The property continued to be in the name of the minor.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The dictionary meaning of "transfer" in K.J. Aiyar's Judicial Dictionary reads amongst others as under:- "Transfer must carry with it "from" and "to".
label: ANALYSIS

text:
In case either of them is wanting, there can be no transfer."
 .
label: ANALYSIS

text: In our opinion, therefore, considering the definition of transfer and the dictionary meaning of transfer, on the facts of this case there would be no transfer in so far as the immovable property is concerned.
label: ANALYSIS

text: 9.  The next aspect of the matter is of the house standing on the said property.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no material to show that the income from which the house was constructed.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The fact, however, remains that the house stands in the records in the name of the petitioner right from the year 1979-80.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This fact is not disputed by Revenue.
label: ANALYSIS

text: Even otherwise the learned Counsel for the petitioner has placed before us the revenue records indicating and which would raise a presumption that the property with the structure (house) atleast from the assessment year 1979-80 stands in the name of the petitioner herein.
label: ANALYSIS

text: There is no material to show that at any point of time that the house was shown in the name of the petitioner's father.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This would be one aspect of the matter.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The other aspect of the matter is even assuming that the house was constructed by the father the transfer in terms of the explanation must be for recovery of the tax arrears of the father for a period prior to the date of the transfer.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The father's dues are for the block assessment years 1986-96.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The house stands in the name of the son from 1979-80.
label: RATIO

text: In our opinion, therefore, considering these facts on record it cannot be said that there has been a gift or exchange or transfer by any other means of the house which would fall within the explanation and consequent thereto respect of which the respondents could have attached and sold the houseand property.
label: RATIO

text:
8.  We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion that the proposed sale of the land and the house by Respondent No.1 is without the authority of law.
 .   In the light of that petition made absolute in terms of prayer clauses (a) and (b).

text: In the circumstances of the case there shall be no order as to costs.

text:
In the assessment year 1956-57 the aggregate of all
depreciation allowances including 'initial depreciation'
exceeded the original cost of machinery but in respect of
that year as well as for the assessment years 1957-58 and
1958-59, the Income Tax Officer failed to deduct 'initial
depreciation and the company was allowed 'normal
depreciation' in, excess of the amount permissible under

text:
The Company filed returns under
protest and thereafter challenged the notices of re-

label: PREAMBLE

text:
It was common ground that excessive
depreciation was in fact allowed to the Company and that
certain income escaped assessment, but it was contended on
behalf of the appellant that the income did not escape
assessment "by reason of the omission or failure on the part
of the assessee to disclose fully and truly all material
facts necessary for assessment of that year".
label: PREAMBLE

text: A Single
label: PREAMBLE

Judge of the High Court held that while the Company
committed no error in failing to take into account the

in its return, it was not open to the Company to set out
only those facts which exaggerated its claim.

rejected the petition.
label: PREAMBLE

text:
In dismissing a Letters Patent
appeal, the High Court took the view that there was

as well as the Income Tax Officer" and that the Income Tax
Officer could reasonably come to the conclusion that it was

due to the omission and failure on the part of the assessee

hereinafter called 'the Company'-was incorporated in 1946.
label: NONE

text: From time to time the Company purchased and installed machi- nery of the value of Rs. 75 lakhs for its factory.
label: FAC

text: In proceedings for assessment of income-tax, the Company was allowed, in computing its income from business for the assessment years 1950-51, 1951-52 and 1952-53 "initial depreciation" aggregating to Rs. 15,91,51 1/- in respect of new machinery installed in the relevant previous years.
label: FAC

text: The Company was also allowed "normal depreciation I' at the appropriate rates.
label: FAC

text: In the assessment year 1956-57 the aggregate of all depreciation allowances including "initial depreciation" exceeded the original cost of the machinery, but the Income-tax Officer on the written down value of the machinery computed at Rs. 16,48,053/- allowed Rs. 2,59,236/- as normal depreciation.
label: FAC

text: In so computing the normal depreciation the Income-tax Officer apparently lost sight of clause (c) of the proviso to s. 10(2) (vi) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.
label: FAC

text: Depreciation allowance was also allowed in the assessment years 1957-58 and 1958-59 as a percentage on the appropriate written down value in those years.
label: FAC

text: The Income- tax Officer on November 20, 1964, issued notices of re- assessment for the three years under s. 148 of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1961, which had replaced the Act of 1922.
label: FAC

text: The Company filed under protest fresh returns and objected to the issue of the notices of reassessment.
label: FAC

text: The Company also moved petitions in the High Court of Allahabad for writs quashing the three notices,. contending inter alia, that the notices issued more than four years after the expiry of the years of assessment were barred.
label: FAC

text: At the hearing of the petitions counsel for the Company conceded that under proviso (c) to s. 10 (2) (vi) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in the form in which it stood in the assessment year 1956-57 and thereafter, excessive depreciation was in fact allowed to the Company.
label: FAC

text: It was also common ground that by virtue of cl. (c) to Explana-tion 1 of s. 147 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, income having been made the subject matter of excessive relief under the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, the income chargeable to tax had escaped assessment.
label: FAC

text: But it was urged that the income had not escaped assessment "by reason of the omission or failure on the part of the assessee to disclose fully and truly, all material facts necessary for assessment of that year", for-(1) the Indian Income-tax Art, 1922, and the forms of returns prescribed under the rules did not require the, assessee to disclose that initial depreciation had been allowed in the earlier years; and (2) that in any event the Income-tax Officer knew that initial depreciation had been allowed to the Company in the years 1950-51, 1951-52 and 1952-53.
label: FAC

text: R. S. Pathak, J., who heard the petitions held that the Company committed no error in failing to take into account the initial depreciation while entering the written down value in column (2) of Part V of the return.
label: FAC

text: But the learned Judge held that it was. incumbent upon the Company to inform the Income-tax Officer of all material facts necessary to make out its claim to depreciation and it was not open to the Company to set out only those facts which exaggerated its claim
label: FAC

text: : the Company was bound to disclose all material facts which went to show what the true amount of the allowance to which it was entitled.
label: FAC

text: The learned Judge accordingly rejected the petitions.
label: FAC

text: The order passed by Pathak, J., was confirmed in appeal under the Letters Patent.
label: FAC

text: By cl. (vi) of sub-s. (2) of s. 10 of the Income-tax Act, 1922, as amended by Act 8 of 1946, in computing the profits or gains.
label: STA

text: of business, profession or vocation carried on by him, an assessee was entitled to allowances not only of normal depreciation but also initial depreciation at the rates set out in cls. (a), (b) & (c) in respect of buildings which had been newly erected, or the machinery or plant being new had been installed after the 3 1st day of March, 1945.
label: FAC

text: It was, however, expressly enacted that the initial depreciation was not deductible in determining the written down value for the purpose of cl. (vi).
label: FAC

text: Allowance for initial depreciation was therefore not to be taken into account in determining the written down value for determining the normal depreciation.
label: FAC

text: But on that account proviso (c) to s. 10 (2) (vi) was not modified.
label: FAC

text: The written down value of the machinery of the, Company in the year 1956-57 was Rs. 16,48,053, but 'for the application of cl. (c) of the proviso to s. 10(2) (vi) the initial depreciation allowed in the years 1950-51, 1951-52 and 1952- 53 had to be taken into account.
label: FAC

text: The Income-tax Officer inadvertently failed to take into account the initial depreciation, and the Company was allowed normal depreciation in the year 1956-57 in excess of the amount permissible under proviso (c) to s. 10(2) (vi).
label: FAC

text: TheIncome-tax Officer later sought to rectify the error and to bring to tax the income which had escaped tax.
label: FAC

text: Before R. S. Pathak, I., it was contended that the definition of written down value" in s. 10(5) (b) applies wherever the expression is used in s. 10(2) and on that account the Company in seting out the written down value in column (2) of Part V of the return was obliged to take into account all the depreciation actually allowed to it including the initial depreciation and as the Company computed the written down value only by deducting the normal depreciation and not the initial depreciation, it failed to' disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for the purpose of assessment.
label: ANALYSIS

text: This argument was not accepted by the learned Judge.
label: ANALYSIS

text: But he was still of the opinion that the Act imposed upon the Company a duty to disclose all material facts which went to show the true amount of the allowances to which it was entitled, and the Company by failing to disclose that initial depreciation had been allowed in three earlier years
label: ANALYSIS

text: , the Company had failed to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for assessment, and on that account s. 147 ( 1 )(a) was attracted and the, notice was properly issued.
label: ANALYSIS

text: In appeal, the High Court observed that the "only question for consideration" was whether the Income-tax Officer was justified in issuing a notice under s. 148 of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
label: ANALYSIS

text: After stating that there was apparently "a mistake and error on the side of the Company as well as the Income-tax Officer", the, Court observed that the Income-tax Officer could reasonably comer to the conclusion that it was due to the omission and failure on the part of the assessee in disclosing fully and truly all material facts necessary for the assessment that the error was committed by the Income-tax Officer as a result of which some income had es- caped assessment.
label: ANALYSIS

text: The High Court then observed : "It is difficult to hold that the Income-tax Officer while issuing the notices under Act could not reasonably hold the assessee was responsible for assessment.", and held that the notices were not Section 34(1) (a) of the Income-tax Act, 1922,
label: ANALYSIS

text: provided: " (1) if- (a) the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that
label: ANALYSIS

text:
by reason of the omission or failure on the part of an assessee to make a return of his income under section 22 for any year or to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year,                         income, profits or, gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment for that year, or have been under assessed, or assessed at too low a rate, or have been made the subject of excessive relief under the Act, or excessive loss or depreciation allowance has been computed, or he may proceed to assess or re-assess such income, profits or gains or re-compute the loss or depreciation allowance; and the provisions of this Act shall, so far as may be, apply accordingly as if the notice were a notice issued under that sub-section :"
Section 34 confers jurisdiction upon the Income-tax Officer to 'issue a notice in respect of the assessment beyond the period of four years, but within a period of eight years, from the end. of the relevant year, if two conditions exist (1) that the Income-tax Officer has reason to believe that income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax had been under-assessed; and (2) that he has also reason to believe that such "under.-assessment" had occurred by reason of either (i) omission or failure on the part of an assessee to make a return of his income under s. 22, or (ii) omission or failure on the part of an assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year.
label: ANALYSIS

text: These ,conditions are cumulative and precedent to the exercise of jurisdiction to issue a notice of re- assessment : Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Companies District 1, Calcutta and Anr.
label: PRE_RELIED

text: (1) In deciding the appeal, the High Court held that the Income-tax Officer did in fact decide that the income had escaped assessment, but the High Court did not consider whether the income escaped assessment by reason of omission or failure on the part of the Company to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary.
label: PRE_RELIED

text: for assessment.

text: The judgment of the High Court is set aside and the case is remanded for determination of the question whether by reason of the omission or failure on the part of the Company to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for assessment of the Company for the three years in question, any income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment or the ,Company has been given excessive depreciation allowance in computing its income.
